questions.question: Organizations requiring employees to take a mandatory vacation each year PRIMARILY want to ensure that:

options.A: adequate cross-training exists between functions.
options.B: an effective internal control environment is in place by increasing morale.
options.C: potential irregularities in processing are identified by a temporary replacement.
options.D: the risk of processing errors is reduced.

justifications.A:
Cross-training is a good practice to follow but can be achieved without the requirement for mandatory
vacation.
justifications.B:
Good employee morale and high levels of employee satisfaction are worthwhile objectives, but they
should not be considered a means to achieve an effective internal control system.
justifications.C:
Employees who perform critical and sensitive functions within an organization should be required
to take some time off to help ensure that irregularities and fraud are detected.
justifications.D:
Although rotating employees can contribute to fewer processing errors, this is not typically a reason to
require a mandatory vacation policy.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is verifying IT policies and finds that some of the policies have not been
approved by management (as required by policy), but the employees strictly follow the policies. What should
the IS auditor do FIRST?

options.A: Ignore the absence of management approval because employees follow the policies.
options.B: Recommend immediate management approval of the policies.
options.C: Emphasize the importance of approval to management.
options.D: Report the absence of documented approval.

justifications.A:
Absence of management approval is an important (material) finding and, although it is not currently an
issue with relation to compliance because the employees are following the policy without approval, it may
be a problem at a later time and should be resolved.
justifications.B:
Although the information systems (IS) auditor would likely recommend that the policies should be
approved as soon as possible and may also remind management of the critical nature of this issue, the first
step is to report this issue to the relevant stakeholders.
justifications.C: The first step is to report the finding and provide recommendations later.
justifications.D:
The IS auditor must report the finding. Unapproved policies may present a potential risk to the
organization, even if they are being followed, because this technicality may prevent management
from enforcing the policies in some cases and may present legal issues. For example, if an employee
was terminated as a result of violating an organizational policy, and it was discovered that the
policies had not been approved, the organization may face a lawsuit
99

questions.question:
What is the PRIMARY consideration for an information systems (IS) auditor reviewing the prioritization and
coordination of IT projects and program management?

options.A: Projects are aligned with the organization's strategy.
options.B: Identified project risk is monitored and mitigated.
options.C: Controls related to project planning and budgeting are appropriate.
options.D: IT project metrics are reported accurately.

justifications.A:
The primary goal of IT projects is to add value to the business, so they must be aligned with the
business strategy to achieve the intended results. Therefore, the information systems (IS) auditor
should first focus on ensuring this alignment.
justifications.B:
An adequate process for monitoring and mitigating identified project risk is important; however, strategic
alignment helps in assessing identified risk in business terms.
justifications.C:
Completion of projects within a predefined time and budget is important; however, the fbcus of project
management should be on achieving the desired outcome of the project, which is aligned with the
business strategy.
justifications.D:
Adequate reporting of project status is important but may or may not help in providing the strategic
perspective of project deliverables.

questions.question:
In a review of the human resources policies and procedures within an organization, an information systems
(IS) auditor is MOST concerned with the absence of a:

options.A: requirement for periodic job rotations.
options.B: process for formalized exit interviews.
options.C: termination checklist.
options.D: requirement for new employees to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

justifications.A:
Job rotation is a valuable control to ensure continuity of operations, but not the most serious human
resources policy risk.
justifications.B: Holding an exit interview is desirable, when possible, to gain feedback but is not a serious risk.
justifications.C:
A termination checklist is critical to ensure the logical and physical security of an enterprise. In
addition to preventing the loss of enterprise property that was issued to the employee, there is the
risk of unauthorized access, intellectual property theft and even sabotage by a disgruntled former
employee.
justifications.D:
Signing a nondisclosure agreement (NDA) is a recommended human resources practice, but a lack of an
NDA is not the most serious risk listed.
100

questions.question:
Which of the following factors is MOST critical when evaluating the effectiveness of an IT governance
implementation?

options.A: Ensure that assurance objectives are defined.
options.B: Determine stakeholder requirements and involvement.
options.C: Identify relevant risk and related opportunities.
options.D: Determine relevant enablers and their applicability.

justifications.A:
Stakeholder needs and involvement form the basis for scoping the IT governance implementation and is
used to define assurance objectives.
justifications.B:
The most critical factor to be considered in auditing an IT governance implementation is to
determine stakeholder requirements and involvement This drives the success of the project. Based
on this, the assurance scope and objectives are determined.
justifications.C: The relevant risk and related opportunities are identified and driven by the assurance objectives.
justifications.D:
The relevant enablers and their applicability for the IT governance implementation are considered based
on assurance objectives.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST reason to implement a policy that places conditions on secondary
employment for IT employees?

options.A: To prevent the misuse of corporate resources
options.B: To prevent conflicts of interest
options.C: To prevent employee performance issues
options.D: To prevent theft of IT assets

justifications.A:
The misuse of corporate resources is an issue that must be addressed but is not necessarily related to
secondary employment.
justifications.B:
The best reason to implement and enforce a policy governing secondary employment is to prevent
conflicts of interest. Policies should be in place to control IT employees seeking secondary
employment from releasing sensitive information or working for a competing organization.
Conflicts of interest can result in serious risk, such as fraud, theft of intellectual property or other
improprieties.
justifications.C:
Employee performance can certainly be an issue if an employee is overworked or has insufficient time
off, but that should be dealt with as a management function and not the primary reason to have a policy on
secondary employment.
justifications.D:
Theft of assets is a problem but not necessarily related to secondary employment.
101

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is assigned to review an organization's information security policy.
Which of the following issues represents the HIGHEST potential risk?

options.A: The policy has not been updated in more than one year.
options.B: The policy includes no revision history.
options.C: The policy is approved by the security administrator.
options.D: The organization does not have an information security policy committee.

justifications.A:
Although the information security policy should be updated on a regular basis, the specific time period
may vary based on the organization. Although reviewing policies annually is a good practice, the policy
may be updated less frequently and still be relevant and effective. An outdated policy is still enforceable,
whereas a policy without proper approval is not enforceable.
justifications.B:
The lack of a revision history with respect to the information security (IS) policy document is an issue
but not as significant as not having it approved by management. A new policy, for example, may not have
been subject to any revisions yet.
justifications.C:
The information security policy should have an owner who has management responsibility for
the development, review, approval and evaluation of the security policy. The position of security
administrator is typically a staff-level position (not management), and therefore does not have
the authority to approve the policy. In addition, an individual in a more independent position
should also review the policy. Without proper management approval, enforcing the policy may be
problematic, leading to compliance or security issues.
justifications.D:
Although a policy committee drawn from across the organization is a good practice and may help write
better policies, a good policy can be written by a single person, and the lack of a committee is not a
problem by itself.

questions.question: What is the PRIMARY reason for an information systems (IS) auditor to exercise due professional care?

options.A: To get reasonable assurance that IS controls are well-designed and effective
options.B: To eliminate inherent, control and detection risk associated with IS audit
options.C: To detect errors, misstatements or fraudulent transactions in IS and report them
options.D: To make sure that evidence collected during the IS audit is appropriate and sufficient

justifications.A:
Exercising due professional care helps the information systems (IS) auditor to get reasonable, but
not absolute, assurance that audit risk is reduced and evidence that is collected about the design
and effectiveness of IS controls is appropriate and sufficient
justifications.B: Risk cannot be eliminated but reduced to an acceptable level.
justifications.C: There is detection risk associated with IS audit that cannot be avoided.
justifications.D:
Evidence collected should be appropriate and sufficient to help provide reasonable assurance about the
design and effectiveness of IS controls.
102

questions.question:
When auditing the IT governance framework and IT risk management practices existing within an enterprise,
the information systems (IS) auditor identified some undefined responsibilities regarding IT management and
governance roles. Which of the following recommendations is the MOST appropriate?

options.A: Review the strategic alignment of IT with the business.
options.B: Implement accountability rules within the enterprise.
options.C: Ensure that independent IS audits are conducted periodically.
options.D: Create a chief risk officer role in the enterprise.

justifications.A:
Although the strategic alignment of IT with the business is important, it is not directly related to the gap
identified in this scenario.
justifications.B:
IT risk is managed by embedding accountability into the enterprise. The information systems
(IS) auditor should recommend the implementation of accountability rules to ensure that all
responsibilities are defined within the enterprise. Note that this question asks for the best
recommendation—not about the finding itself
justifications.C:
Performing more frequent IS audits is not helpful if the accountability rules are not clearly defined and
implemented.
justifications.D:
Recommending the creation of a new role (e.g., chief risk officer) is not helpful if the accountability rules
are not clearly defined and implemented.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is performing a review of the software quality management process in an
organization. The FIRST step should be to:

options.A: Verify how the organization complies with the standards.
options.B: Identify and report the existing controls.
options.C: Review the metrics for quality evaluation.
options.D: Request all standards adopted by the organization.

justifications.A:
The auditor needs to know what standards the organization has adopted and then measure compliance
with those standards. Determining how the organization follows the standards is secondary to knowing
what the standards are.
justifications.B:
The first step is to know the standards and what policies and procedures are mandated for the
organization, then to document the controls and measure compliance.
justifications.C:
The metrics cannot be reviewed until the auditor has a copy of the standards that describe or require the
metrics.
justifications.D:
Because an audit measures compliance with the standards of the organization, the first step of the
review of the software quality management process should be to determine the evaluation criteria
in the form of standards adopted by the organization. The evaluation of how well the organization
follows its own standards cannot be performed until the information systems (IS) auditor has
determined what standards exist
103

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor found that the enterprise architecture (EA) recently adopted by an
organization has an adequate current-state representation. However, the organization has started a separate
project to develop a future-state representation. The IS auditor should:

options.A: Recommend that this separate project be completed as soon as possible.
options.B: Report this issue as a finding in the audit report.
options.C: Recommend the adoption of the Zachmann framework.
options.D: Rescope the audit to include the separate project as part of the cunent audit.

justifications.A:
The information systems (IS) auditor does not ordinarily provide input on the timing of projects, but
rather provides an assessment of the current environment. The most critical issue in this scenario is that
the enterprise architecture (EA) is undergoing change, so the IS auditor should be most concerned with
reporting this issue.
justifications.B:
It is critical for the EA to include the future state because the gap between the current state and the
future state will determine IT strategic and tactical plans. If the EA does not include a future-state
representation, it is not complete, and this issue should be reported as a finding.
justifications.C:
The organization is free to choose any EA framework, and the IS auditor should not recommend a specific
framework.
justifications.D:
Changing the scope of an audit to include the secondary project is not required, although a follow-up
audit may be desired.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is evaluating managemenfs risk assessment of information systems. The
IS auditor should FIRST review the:

options.A: controls in place.
options.B: effectiveness of the controls.
options.C: mechanism for monitoring the risk.
options.D: threats/vulnerabilities affecting the assets.

justifications.A:
The controls are irrelevant until the information systems (IS) auditor knows the threats and risk that the
controls are intended to address.
justifications.B:
The effectiveness of the controls must be measured in relation to the risk (based on assets, threats and
vulnerabilities) that the controls are intended to address.
justifications.C:
The first step must be to determine the risk that is being managed before reviewing the mechanism of
monitoring risk.
justifications.D:
One of the key factors to be considered while assessing the information systems risk is the value of
the systems (the assets) and the threats and vulnerabilities affecting the assets. The risk related to
the use of information assets should be evaluated in isolation from the installed controls.
104 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition

questions.question: The PRIMARY benefit of an enterprise architecture initiative is to:

options.A: enable the enterprise to invest in the most appropriate technology.
options.B: ensure security controls are implemented on critical platforms.
options.C: allow development teams to be more responsive to business requirements.
options.D: provide business units with greater autonomy to select IT solutions that fit their needs.

justifications.A: The primary focus of the enterprise architecture (EA) is to ensure that technology investments are consistent with the platform, data and development standards of the IT organization; therefore, the goal of the EA is to help the organization to implement the technology that is most effective.
justifications.B: Ensuring that security controls are implemented on critical platforms is important, but this is not the function of the EA. The EA may be concerned with the design of security controls; however, the EA does not help to ensure that they were implemented. The primary focus of the EA is to ensure that technology investments are consistent with the platform, data and development standards of the IT organization.
justifications.C: Although the EA process may enable development teams to be more efficient, because they are creating solutions based on standard platforms using standard programming languages and methods, the more critical benefit of the EA is to provide guidance for IT investments of all types, which encompasses much more than software development.
justifications.D: A primary focus of the EA is to define standard platforms, databases and interfaces. Business units that invest in technology need to select IT solutions that meet their business needs and are compatible with the EA of the enterprise. There may be instances when a proposed solution works better for a business unit but is not at all consistent with the EA of the enterprise, so there would be a need to compromise to ensure that the application can be supported by IT. Overall, the EA would restrict the ability of business units in terms of the potential IT systems that they may wish to implement. The support requirements would not be affected in this case.

questions.question: Which of the following situations is addressed by a software escrow agreement?

options.A: The system administrator requires access to software to recover from a disaster.
options.B: A user requests to have software reloaded onto a replacement hard drive.
options.C: The vendor of custom-written software goes out of business.
options.D: An information systems (IS) auditor requires access to software code written by the organization.

justifications.A:
Access to software should be managed by an internally managed software library. Escrow refers to the
storage of software with a third party~~not the internal libraries.
justifications.B:
Providing the user with a backup copy of software is not escrow. Escrow requires that a copy be kept with
a trusted third party.
justifications.C:
A software escrow is a legal agreement between a software vendor and a customer to guarantee
access to source code. The application source code is held by a trusted third party, according to the
contract. This agreement is necessary in the event that the software vendor goes out of business,
there is a contractual dispute with the customer or the software vendor fails to maintain an update
of the software as promised in the software license agreement.
justifications.D:
Software escrow is used to protect the intellectual property of software developed by one organization
and sold to another organization. This is not used for software being reviewed by an auditor of the
organization that wrote the software.

questions.question: An information systems (IS) auditor reviews an organizational chart PRIMARILY for:

options.A: understanding of the complexity of the organizational structure.
options.B: investigating various communication channels.
options.C: understanding the responsibilities and authority of individuals.
options.D: investigating the network connected to different employees.

justifications.A:
Understanding the complexity of the organizational structure is not the primary reason to review an
organizational chart because the chart does not necessarily depict the complexity.
justifications.B:
The organizational chart is a key tool for an auditor to understand roles and responsibilities and reporting
lines but is not used for examining communications channels.
justifications.C:
An organizational chart provides information about the responsibilities and authority of individuals
in the organization. This helps an information systems (IS) auditor to know if there is a proper
segregation of functions.
justifications.D:
A network diagram provides information about the usage of various communication channels and
indicates the connection of users to the network.

questions.question: Sharing risk is a key factor in which of the following methods of managing risk?

options.A: Transferring risk
options.B: Tolerating risk
options.C: Terminating risk
options.D: Treating risk

justifications.A: Transferring risk (e・g., by taking an insurance policy) is a way to share risk.
justifications.B: Tolerating risk means that the risk is accepted, but not shared.
justifications.C:
Terminating risk does not involve sharing the risk because the organization has chosen to terminate the
process associated with the risk.
justifications.D:
There are several ways of treating or controlling the risk, which may involve reducing or sharing the risk,
but this is not as precise an answer as transferring the risk.
106

questions.question:
A team conducting a risk analysis is having difficulty projecting the financial losses that can result from a risk.
To evaluate the potential impact, the team should:

options.A: compute the amortization of the related assets.
options.B: calculate a return on investment (ROI).
options.C: apply a qualitative approach.
options.D: spend the time needed to define the loss amount exactly.

justifications.A: Amortization is used in a profit and loss statement, not in computing potential losses.
justifications.B:
A return on investment (ROI) is computed when there is predictable savings or revenues that can be
compared to the investment needed to realize the revenues.
justifications.C:
The common practice when it is difficult to calculate the financial losses is to take a qualitative
approach, in which the manager affected by the risk defines the impact in terms of a weighted
factor (e.g., one is a very low impact to the business and five is a very high impact).
justifications.D:
Spending the time needed to define exactly the total amount is normally a wrong approach. If it has
been difficult to estimate potential losses (e.g., losses derived from erosion of public image due to a hack
attack), that situation is not likely to change, and the result will not be a well-supported evaluation.

questions.question:
While reviewing a quality management system, the information systems (IS) auditor should PRIMARILY
focus on collecting evidence to show that:

options.A: quality management systems comply with good practices.
options.B: continuous improvement targets are being monitored.
options.C: standard operating procedures are updated annually.
options.D: key performance indicators are defined.

justifications.A:
Generally, good practices are adopted according to business requirements. Therefore, conforming to good
practices may or may not be a requirement of the business.
justifications.B:
Continuous and measurable improvement of quality is the primary requirement to achieve the
business objective for the quality management system (QMS).
justifications.C:
Updating operating procedures is part of implementing the QMS; however, it must be part of change
management and not an annual activity.
justifications.D:
Key performance indicators may be defined in a QMS, but they are of little value if they are not being
monitored.
107

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers several IT-based projects were implemented and not approved
by the steering committee. What is the GREATEST concern for the IS auditor?

options.A: The IT departmenfs projects will not be adequately funded.
options.B: IT projects are not following the system development life cycle (SDLC) process.
options.C: IT projects are not consistently formally approved.
options.D: The IT department may not be working toward a common goal.

justifications.A:
Funding for the projects may be addressed through various budgets and may not require steering
committee approval. The primary concern is to ensure that the project is working toward meeting the
goals of the enterprise.
justifications.B:
Although requiring steering committee approval may be part of the system development life cycle
(SDLC) process, the greater concern is whether the projects are working toward the corporate goals.
Without steering committee approval, it is difficult to determine whether these projects are following the
direction of the corporate goals.
justifications.C:
Although having a formal approval process is important, the greatest concern is for the steering
committee to provide corporate direction for the projects.
justifications.D:
The steering committee provides direction and control over projects to ensure that the enterprise is
making appropriate investments. Without approval, the project may or may not be working toward
the enterprise goals.

questions.question: Value delivery from IT to the business is MOST effectively achieved by:

options.A: aligning the IT strategy with the enterprise strategy
options.B: embedding accountability in the enterprise
options.C: providing a positive return on investment
options.D: establishing an enterprisewide risk management process

justifications.A: IT's value delivery to the business is driven by aligning IT with the enterprise's strategy.
justifications.B:
Embedding accountability in the enterprise promotes risk management (another element of corporate
governance).
justifications.C: While return on investment is important, it is not the only criterion by which the value of IT is assessed.
justifications.D:
Enterprise-wide risk management is critical to IT governance; however, by itself, it will not guarantee that
IT delivers value to the business unless the IT strategy is aligned with the enterprise strategy.
108

questions.question:
During a feasibility study regarding outsourcing IT processing, the relevance for the information systems (IS)
auditor of reviewing the vendor's business continuity plan is to:

options.A: evaluate the adequacy of the service levels that the vendor can provide in a contingency.
options.B: evaluate the financial stability of the service bureau and its ability to fulfill the contract.
options.C: review the experience of the vendor's staff.
options.D: test the business continuity plan.

justifications.A:
A key factor in a successful outsourcing environment is the capability of the vendor to face a
contingency and continue to support the organization's processing requirements.
justifications.B: Financial stability is not related to the vendor's business continuity plan (BCP).
justifications.C: Experience of the vendor's staff is not related to the vendor's BCP.
justifications.D: The review of the vendor's BCP during a feasibility study is not a way to test the vendor's BCP.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is evaluating a newly developed IT policy for an organization. Which of
the following factors does the IS auditor consider MOST important to facilitate compliance with the policy
upon its implementation?

options.A: Existing IT mechanisms enabling compliance
options.B: Alignment of the policy to the business strategy
options.C: Current and future technology initiatives
options.D: Regulatory compliance objectives defined in the policy

justifications.A:
The organization should be able to comply with a policy when it is implemented. The most
important consideration when evaluating the new policy should be the existing mechanisms in
place that enable the organization and its employees to comply with the policy.
justifications.B:
Policies should be aligned with the business strategy, but this does not affect an organization's ability to
comply with the policy upon implementation.
justifications.C:
Current and future technology initiatives should be driven by the needs of the business and does not affect
an organization's ability to comply with the policy.
justifications.D:
Regulatory compliance objectives may be defined in the IT policy, but that does not facilitate compliance
with the policy. Defining objectives only results in the organization knowing the desired state and does
not aid in achieving compliance.
109

questions.question: The MOST likely effect of the lack of senior management commitment to IT strategic planning is:

options.A: lack of investment in technology.
options.B: lack of a methodology for systems development.
options.C: Technology not aligning with organization objectives.
options.D: absence of control over technology contracts.

justifications.A:
Lack of management commitment almost certainly affects investment, but the primary loss is the lack of
alignment of IT strategy with the strategy of the business.
justifications.B: Systems development methodology is a process-related function and not a key concern of management.
justifications.C:
A steering committee should exist to ensure that the IT strategies support the organization's goals.
The absence of an information technology committee or a committee not composed of senior
managers is an indication of a lack of top-level management commitment This condition increases
the risk that IT is not aligned with organization strategy.
justifications.D:
Approval for contracts is a business process and is controlled through financial process controls. This is
not applicable here.

questions.question: Which of the following is a function of an IT steering committee?

options.A: Monitoring vendor-controlled change control and testing
options.B: Ensuring a separation of duties within the information^ processing environment
options.C: Approving and monitoring the status of IT plans and budgets
options.D: Liaising between the IT department and end users

justifications.A: Vendor change control is a sourcing issue and should be monitored by IT management.
justifications.B:
Ensuring a separation of duties within the information^ processing environment is an IT management
responsibility.
justifications.C:
The IT steering committee typically serves as a general review board for major IT projects and
should not become involved in routine operations; therefore, one of its functions is to approve and
monitor major projects, such as the status of IT plans and budgets.
justifications.D:
Liaising between the IT department and end users is a function of the individual parties and not a
committee responsibility.
110

questions.question: Involvement of senior management is MOST important in the development of:

options.A: strategic plans.
options.B: IT policies.
options.C: IT procedures.
options.D: standards and guidelines.

justifications.A:
Strategic plans provide the basis for ensuring that the enterprise meets its goals and objectives.
Involvement of senior management is critical to ensuring that the plan adequately addresses the
established goals and objectives.
justifications.B:
IT policies are created and enforced by IT management and information security. They are structured to
support the overall strategic plan.
justifications.C:
IT procedures are developed to support IT policies. Senior management is not involved in the
development of procedures.
justifications.D:
Standards and guidelines are developed to support IT policies. Senior management is not involved in the
development of standards, baselines and guidelines.
Ill

questions.question: Effective IT governance ensures that the IT plan is consistent with the organization's:

options.A: business plan.
options.B: audit plan.
options.C: security plan.
options.D: investment plan.

justifications.A:
To govern IT effectively, IT and business should be moving in the same direction, requiring that the
IT plans are aligned with an organization^ business plans.
justifications.B: The audit plan is not part of the IT plan.
justifications.C: The security plan is not a responsibility of IT and does not need to be consistent with the IT plan.
justifications.D: The investment plan is not part of the IT plan.

questions.question: Establishing the level of acceptable risk is the responsibility of:

options.A: quality assurance management.
options.B: senior business management.
options.C: the chief information officer.
options.D: the chief security officer.

justifications.A:
Quality assurance (QA) is concerned with reliability and consistency of processes. The QA team is not
responsible for determining an acceptable risk level.
justifications.B:
Senior management should establish the acceptable risk level because it has the ultimate or final
responsibility for the effective and efficient operation of the organization as senior management of
the business process. The person can be the QA manager, chief information officer (CIO) or chief
security officer (CSO), if they are the business manager Responsibility for establishing the level of
acceptable risk rests with the business manager
justifications.C:
The establishment of acceptable risk levels is a senior business management responsibility. The CIO is
the most senior official of the enterprise who is accountable for IT advocacy; aligning IT and business
strategies; and planning, resourcing and managing the delivery of IT services, information and the
deployment of associated human resources. The CIO is rarely the person who determines acceptable risk
levels because this could be a conflict of interest unless the CIO is the senior business process owner.
justifications.D:
The establishment of acceptable risk levels is a senior business management responsibility. The CSO is
responsible for enforcing the decisions of the senior management team unless the CIO is the business
process manager.

questions.question: IT governance is PRIMARILY the responsibility of the:

options.A: CEO.
options.B: board of directors.
options.C: IT steering committee.
options.D: audit committee.

justifications.A:
The CEO is instrumental in implementing IT governance according to the directions of the board of
directors.
justifications.B:
IT governance is primarily the responsibility of the executives and shareholders (as represented by
the board of directors).
justifications.C:
The IT steering committee monitors and facilitates deployment of IT resources for specific projects in
support of business plans. The IT steering committee enforces governance on behalf of the board of
directors.
justifications.D:
The audit committee reports to the board of directors and executes governance-related audits. The audit
committee should monitor the implementation of audit recommendations.

questions.question: From a control perspective, the key element in job descriptions is that they:

options.A: provide instructions on how to do the job and define authority.
options.B: are current, documented and readily available to the employee.
options.C: communicate managemenfs specific job performance expectations.
options.D: establish responsibility and accountability for the employee's actions.

justifications.A:
Providing instructions on how to do the job and defining authority addresses the managerial and
procedural aspects of the job and is a management responsibility. Job descriptions, which are a HR-related
function, are primarily used to establish job requirements and accountability.
justifications.B:
It is important that job descriptions are current, documented and readily available to the employee, but
this, in itself； is not the key element of the job description. Job descriptions, which are an HR-related
function, are primarily used to establish job requirements and accountability.
justifications.C:
Communication of managemenfs specific expectations for job performance would not necessarily be
included in job descriptions.
justifications.D:
From a control perspective, a job description should establish responsibility and accountability.
This aids in ensuring that users are given system access in accordance with their defined job
responsibilities and are accountable for how they use that access.
113

questions.question: Which of the following BEST provides assurance of the integrity of new staff?

options.A: Background screening
options.B: References
options.C: Bonding
options.D: Qualifications listed on a resume

justifications.A:
A background screening is the primary method for assuring the integrity of a prospective staff
member This may include criminal history checks, driver's license abstracts, financial status
checks, verification of education, etc.
justifications.B:
References are important and need to be verified, but they are not as reliable as background screening,
because the references themselves may not be validated as trustworthy.
justifications.C: Bonding is directed at due-diligence compliance and does not ensure integrity.
justifications.D:
Qualifications listed on a resume may be used to demonstrate proficiency but will not indicate the
integrity of the candidate employee.

questions.question: When an employee is terminated from service, the MOST important action is to:

options.A: hand over all of the employee's files to another designated employee.
options.B: complete a backup of the employee's work.
options.C: notify other employees of the termination.
options.D: disable the employee's logical access.

justifications.A:
All the work of the terminated employee needs to be handed over to a designated employee; however, this
is not as critical as removing terminated employee access.
justifications.B:
All the work of the terminated employee needs to be backed up, but this is not as critical as removing
terminated employee access.
justifications.C:
The employees need to be notified of the termination, but this is not as critical as removing terminated
employee access.
justifications.D:
There is a probability that a terminated employee may misuse access rights; therefore, disabling the
terminated employee's logical access is the most important and immediate action to take.
114

questions.question:
A business unit has selected a new accounting application and did not consult with IT early in the selection
process. The PRIMARY risk is that the:

options.A: security controls of the application may not meet requirements.
options.B: application may not meet the requirements of the business users.
options.C: application technology may be inconsistent with the enterprise architecture.
options.D: application may create unanticipated support issues for IT.

justifications.A:
Although security controls should be a requirement for any application, the primary fbcus of the
enterprise architecture (EA) is to ensure that new applications are consistent with enterprise standards.
Although the use of standard supported technology may be more secure, this is not the primary benefit of
the EA.
justifications.B:
When selecting an application, the business requirements and the suitability of the application for the
IT environment must be considered. If the business unit selects its application without IT involvement,
it is more likely to choose a solution that fits its business process the best with less emphasis on how
compatible and supportable the solution will be in the enterprise, and this is not a concern.
justifications.C:
The primary focus of the EA is to ensure that technology investments are consistent with the
platform, data and development standards of the IT organization. The EA defines both a current
and future state in areas such as the use of standard platforms, databases or programming
languages. If a business unit selected an application using a database or operating system that
is not part of the EA for the business, this increases the cost and complexity of the solution and
ultimately delivers less value to the business.
justifications.D:
Although any new software implementation may create support issues, the primary benefit of the EA is
ensuring that the IT solutions deliver value to the business. Decreased support costs may be a benefit of
the EA, but the lack of IT involvement in this case does not affect the support requirements.

questions.question: Many organizations require an employee to take a mandatory vacation (holiday) of a week or more to:

options.A: ensure that the employee maintains a good quality of life, which will lead to greater productivity.
options.B: reduce the opportunity for an employee to commit an improper or illegal act.
options.C: provide proper cross-training for another employee.
options.D: eliminate the potential disruption caused when an employee takes vacation one day at a time.

justifications.A:
Maintaining a good quality of life is important, but the primary reason for a mandatory vacation is to
catch fraud or errors.
justifications.B:
Required vacations/holidays of a week or more in duration in which someone other than the regular
employee performs the job function of the employee on vacation is often mandatory for sensitive
positions because this reduces the opportunity to commit improper or illegal acts. During this time
off, it may be possible to discover any fraudulent activity that was taking place.
justifications.C:
Providing cross-training is an important management function, but the primary reason for mandatory
vacations is to detect fraud or errors.
justifications.D:
Enforcing a rule that all vacations must be taken a week at a time is a management decision but not
related to a mandatory vacation policy. The primary reason for mandatory vacations is to detect fraud or
errors.
115

questions.question: A local area network (LAN) administrator normally is restricted from:

options.A: having end-user responsibilities.
options.B: reporting to the end-user manager.
options.C: having programming responsibilities.
options.D: being responsible for LAN security administration.

justifications.A: Although not ideal, a local area network (LAN) administrator may have end-user responsibilities.
justifications.B:
The LAN administrator may report to the director of the information processing facility (IPF) or, in a
decentralized operation, to the end-user manager.
justifications.C:
A LAN administrator should not have programming responsibilities because that can allow
modification of production programs without proper separation of duties, but the LAN
administrator may have end-user responsibilities.
justifications.D:
In small organizations, the LAN administrator may also be responsible for security administration over
the LAN.

questions.question: A decision support system (DSS) is used to help high-level management:

options.A: solve highly structured problems.
options.B: combine the use of decision models with predetermined criteria.
options.C: make decisions based on data analysis and interactive models.
options.D: support only structured decision-making tasks.

justifications.A: A decision support system (DSS) is aimed at solving less-structured problems.
justifications.B:
A DSS combines the use of models and analytic techniques with traditional data access and retrieval
functions but is not limited by predetermined criteria.
justifications.C:
A DSS emphasizes flexibility in the decision-making approach of management through data
analysis and the use of interactive models, not fixed criteria.
justifications.D:
A DSS supports semi-structured decision-making tasks.

questions.question:
During an audit, the information systems (IS) auditor discovers that the HR department uses a cloud-based
application to manage employee records. The HR department engaged in a contract outside of the normal
vendor management process and manages the application on its own. Which of the following is of
GREATEST concern?

options.A: Maximum acceptable downtime metrics have not been defined in the contract.
options.B: The IT department does not manage the relationship with the cloud vendor.
options.C: The help desk call center is in a different country, with different privacy requirements.
options.D: Organization-defined security policies are not applied to the cloud application.

justifications.B:
The responsibility for managing the relationship with a third party should be assigned to a designated
individual or service management team; however, it is not essential that the individual or team belong to
the IT department.
justifications.C:
An organization-defined security policy ensures that help desk personnel do not have access to personnel
data, and this is covered under the security policy. The more critical issue is whether the application
complied with the security policy.
justifications.D:
Cloud applications should adhere to the organization-defined security policies to ensure that the
data in the cloud are protected in a manner consistent with internal applications. These include,
but are not limited to, the password policy, user access management policy and data classification
policy.

questions.question: Before implementing an IT balanced scorecard, an organization must:

options.A: deliver effective and efficient services.
options.B: define key performance indicators.
options.C: provide business value to IT projects.
options.D: control IT expenses.

justifications.A:
A balanced scorecard (BSC) is a method of specifying and measuring the attainment of strategic results. It
measures the delivery of effective and efficient services, but an organization may not have those in place
prior to using a BSC.
justifications.B:
Because a BSC is a way to measure performance, a definition of key performance indicators is
required before implementing an IT BSC.
justifications.C:
B. Because a BSC is a way to measure performance, a definition of key performance indicators is
required before implementing an IT BSC.
justifications.D:
A BSC measures the performance of IT, but the control over IT expenses is not a key requirement for
implementing a BSC.
117

questions.question: To support an organization's goals, an IT department should have:

options.A: a low-cost philosophy.
options.B: long- and short-term plans.
options.C: leading-edge technology.
options.D: plans to acquire new hardware and software.

justifications.A:
A low-cost philosophy is one objective, but more important is the cost-benefit and the relation of IT
investment cost to business strategy.
justifications.B:
To ensure its contribution to the realization of an organization's overall goals, the IT department
should have long- and short-range plans that are consistent with the organization's broader and
strategic plans for attaining its goals.
justifications.C:
Leading-edge technology is an objective, but IT plans are needed to ensure that those plans are aligned
with organizational goals.
justifications.D:
Plans to acquire new hardware and software can be a part of the overall plan but are required only if
hardware or software is needed to achieve the organizational goals.

questions.question: In reviewing the IT short-range (tactical) plan, an information systems (IS) auditor should determine whether:

options.A: there is an integration of IT and business personnel within projects.
options.B: there is a clear definition of the IT mission and vision.
options.C: a strategic information technology planning scorecard is in place.
options.D: the plan correlates business objectives to IT goals and objectives.

justifications.A:
The integration of IT and business personnel in projects is an operational issue and should be
considered while reviewing the short-range plan. A strategic plan provides a framework for the IT
short-range plan.
justifications.B: A clear definition of the IT mission and vision is covered by a strategic plan.
justifications.C: A strategic information technology planning scorecard is covered by a strategic plan.
justifications.D:
Business objectives correlating to IT goals and objectives are covered by a strategic plan.
118 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manua!13th Edition

questions.question:
Which of the following does an information systems (IS) auditor consider the MOST relevant to short-term
planning for an IT department?

options.A: Allocating resources
options.B: Adapting to changing technologies
options.C: Conducting control sei仁assessments (CSAs)
options.D: Evaluating hardware needs

justifications.A:
The IT department should specifically consider the way resources are allocated in the short term.
The information systems (IS) auditor ensures that the resources are being managed adequately.
justifications.B:
Investments in IT need to be aligned with top management strategies rather than relevant to short-term
planning and focused on technology.
justifications.C:
Conducting control sel^assessments (CSAs) is not as critical as allocating resources during short-term
planning for the IT department.
justifications.D:
Evaluating hardware needs is not as critical as allocating resources during short-term planning for the IT
department.

questions.question: Which of the following goals do you expect to find in an organization's strategic plan?

options.A: Results of new software testing
options.B: An evaluation of information technology needs
options.C: Short-term project plans for a new planning system
options.D: Approved suppliers for products offered by the organization

justifications.A: Results of a new accounting package is a tactical or short-term goal and is included in a strategic plan.
justifications.B:
An evaluation of information technology needs is a way to measure performance, but not a goal to be
found in a strategic plan.
justifications.C:
Short-term project plans is project-oriented and is a method of implementing a goal but not the goal in
itself. The goal is to have better project management~~the new system is how to achieve that goal.
justifications.D:
Approved suppliers of choice for the product is a strategic business objective that is intended to
focus the overall direction of the business and, thus, is a part of the organization's strategic plan.

questions.question:
Which of the following does an information systems (IS) auditor consider to be MOST important when
evaluating an organization's IT strategy? That it:

options.A: was approved by line management.
options.B: does not vary from the IT departmenfs preliminary budget.
options.C: complies with procurement procedures.
options.D: supports the business objectives of the organization.

justifications.A:
A strategic plan is a senior management responsibility and receives input from line managers but is not
approved by them.
justifications.B: The budget should not vary from the plan.
justifications.C: Procurement procedures are organizational controls, but not a part of strategic planning.
justifications.D:
Strategic planning sets corporate or department objectives into motion. Both long-term and short­
term strategic plans should be consistent with the organization^ broader plans and its business
objectives for attaining these goals.

questions.question:
An organization has contracted with a vendor for a turnkey solution for its electronic toll collection system
(ETCS). The vendor has provided its proprietary application software as part of the solution. The contract
should require that:

options.A: a backup server is available to run ETCS operations with up-to-date data.
options.B: a backup server is loaded with all relevant software and data.
options.C: the systems staff of the organization is trained to handle any event.
options.D: source code of the ETCS application is placed in escrow.

justifications.A:
Having a backup server with current data is critical but not as critical as ensuring the availability of the
source code.
justifications.B:
Having a backup server with relevant software is critical but not as critical as ensuring the availability of
the source code.
justifications.C:
Having staff training is critical but not as critical as ensuring the availability of the source code.
D・ Whenever proprietary application software is purchased, the contract should provide for a source
code escrow agreement This agreement ensures that the purchasing organization can modify the
software if the vendor ceases to be in business.

questions.question:
When reviewing the IT strategy, an information systems (IS) auditor can BEST assess whether the strategy
supports the organizations5 business objectives by determining whether IT:

options.A: has all the personnel and equipment it needs.
options.B: plans are consistent with management strategy.
options.C: uses its equipment and personnel efficiently and effectively.
options.D: has sufficient excess capacity to respond to changing directions.

justifications.A:
Having personnel and equipment is an important requirement to meet the IT strategy but does not ensure
that the IT strategy supports business objectives.
justifications.B:
The only way to know if IT strategy meets business objectives is to determine if the IT plan is
consistent with management strategy and that it relates IT planning to business plans.
justifications.C:
Using equipment and personnel efficiently and effectively is an effective method for determining the
proper management of the IT function but does not ensure that the IT strategy is aligned with business
objectives.
justifications.D:
Having sufficient excess capacity to respond to changing directions is important to show flexibility to
meet organizational changes but is not in itself a way to ensure that IT is aligned with business goals.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor of a large organization is reviewing the roles and responsibilities of the
IT function and finds some individuals serving multiple roles. Which one of the following combinations of
roles should be of GREATEST concern for the IS auditor?

options.A: Network administrators are responsible for quality assurance.
options.B: System administrators are application programmers.
options.C: End users are security administrators for critical applications.
options.D: Systems analysts are database administrators (DBAs).

justifications.A:
Ideally, network administrators should not be responsible for quality assurance because they can approve
their own work. However, that is not as serious as the combination of system administrator and
application programmer, which allows nearly unlimited abuse of privilege.
justifications.B:
When individuals serve multiple roles, this represents a separation-of-duties problem with
associated risk. System administrators should not be application programmers, due to the
associated rights of both functions. A person with both system and programming rights can do
almost anything on a system, including creating a back door. The other combinations of roles are
valid from a separation-of-duties perspective.
justifications.C: In some distributed environments, especially with small staffing levels, users may also manage security.
justifications.D:
Although a database administrator (DBA) is a very privileged position it is not in conflict with the role of
a systems analyst.
121

questions.question:
Which of the following is the GREATEST risk of an inadequate policy definition for ownership of data and
systems?

options.A: User management coordination does not exist.
options.B: Specific user accountability cannot be established.
options.C: Unauthorized users may have access to modify data.
options.D: Audit recommendations may not be implemented.

justifications.A:
The greatest risk is from unauthorized users being able to modify data. User management is important but
not the greatest risk.
justifications.B: User accountability is important but not as great a risk as the actions of unauthorized users.
justifications.C:
Without a policy defining who has the responsibility for granting access to specific systems, there
is an increased risk that individuals can gain (be given) system access when they should not
have authorization. The ability of unauthorized users to modify data is greater than the risk of
authorized user accounts not being controlled properly.
justifications.D:
The failure to implement audit recommendations is a management problem but not as serious as the
ability of unauthorized users to make modifications.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) audit department is planning to minimize the risk of short-term employees.
Activities contributing to this objective are documented procedures, knowledge sharing, cross-training and:

options.A: succession planning.
options.B: staff job evaluation.
options.C: responsibilities definitions.
options.D: employee award programs.

justifications.A:
Succession planning ensures that internal personnel with the potential to fill key positions in the
organization are identified and developed.
justifications.B:
Job evaluation is the process of determining the worth of one job in relation to that of the other jobs in an
organization so that a fair and equitable wage and salary system can be established.
justifications.C:
Staff responsibilities definitions provide for well-defined roles and responsibilities; however, they do not
minimize dependency on key individuals.
justifications.D:
Employee award programs provide motivation; however, they do not minimize dependency on key
individuals.
122

questions.question: Information systems (IS) audit objectives MAINLY focus on:

options.A: assuring compliance with business legal and regulatory requirements.
options.B:
ensuring that information systems (IS) controls exist to minimize business risk to an acceptable level and
function as expected.
options.C: reviewing the IS general controls, objectives and whether those controls operate effectively.
options.D: determining if there is potential risk to the organization's IS assets and finding ways to minimize that risk.

justifications.A:
To ensure that compliance risk is reduced and the information assets are protected, relevant information
systems (IS) controls should be reviewed in terms of their objectives and effectiveness.
justifications.B:
The main focus of IS audit objectives is to confirm whether IS controls are well-designed and
effective to reduce business risk to an acceptable level.
justifications.C:
IS audit objectives include reviewing different types of IS controls, not only general controls, and their
objectives and effectiveness.
justifications.D:
The main fbcus of the risk management process is determining potential risk. IS audit objectives focus on
IS controls placed to reduce business risk to an acceptable level and whether those controls are efiective
and function as expected.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor finds that not all employees are aware of the enterprise's information
security policy. The IS auditor should conclude that:

options.A: this lack of knowledge may lead to unintentional disclosure of sensitive information.
options.B: information security is not critical to all functions.
options.C: IS audit should provide security training to the employees.
options.D: the audit finding will cause management to provide continuous training to staff.

justifications.A:
All employees should be aware of the enterprise's information security policy to prevent
unintentional disclosure of sensitive information. Training is a preventive control. Security
awareness programs for employees can prevent unintentional disclosure of sensitive information
to outsiders.
justifications.B:
Information security is everybody's business, and all staff should be trained in how to handle information
correctly.
justifications.C: Providing security awareness training is not an information systems (IS) audit function.
justifications.D:
Management may agree to or reject an audit finding. The IS auditor cannot be assured that management
will act upon an audit finding unless they are aware of its impact; therefore, the auditor must report the
risk associated with lack of security awareness.
123

questions.question: Which of the following is responsible for the approval of an information security policy?

options.A: IT department
options.B: Security committee
options.C: Security administrator
options.D: Board of directors

justifications.A:
The IT department is responsible for the execution of the policy, having no authority in framing the
policy.
justifications.B: The security committee also functions within the broad security policy framed by the board of directors.
justifications.C:
The security administrator is responsible for implementing, monitoring and enforcing the security rules
that management established and authorized.
justifications.D:
Normally, the approval of an information systems security policy is the responsibility of top
management or the board of directors.

questions.question:
While reviewing the IT governance processes of an organization, an information systems (IS) auditor
discovers the firm has recently implemented an IT balanced scorecard (BSC). The implementation is
complete; however, the IS auditor notices that performance indicators are not objectively measurable. What is
the PRIMARY risk presented by this situation?

options.A:
Key performance indicators are not reported to management and management cannot determine the
effectiveness of the BSC.
options.B: IT projects could suffer from cost overruns.
options.C: Misleading indications of IT performance may be presented to management.
options.D: IT service level agreements may not be accurate.

justifications.A:
If the performance indicators are not objectively measurable, the most significant risk is the presentation
of misleading performance results to management. This can create a false sense of assurance and, as a
result, IT resources may be misallocated, or strategic decisions may be based on incorrect information.
Whether or not the performance indicators are correctly defined, the results would be reported to
management.
justifications.B:
Although project management issues can arise from performance indicators that were not correctly
defined, the presentation of misleading performance to management is a much more significant risk.
justifications.C:
The IT balanced scorecard is designed to measure IT performance. To measure performance, a
sufficient number of performance drivers (key performance indicators [KPIs]) must be defined and
measured over time. Failure to have objective KPIs may result in arbitrary, subjective measures
that may be misleading and lead to unsound decisions.
justifications.D:
Although performance management issues related to service level agreements can arise from performance
indicators that were not correctly defined, the presentation of misleading performance to management is a
much more significant risk.
124

questions.question: Which of the following should be included in an organization^ information security policy?

options.A: A list of key IT resources to be secured
options.B: The basis for access control authorization
options.C: Identity of sensitive security assets
options.D: Relevant software security features

justifications.A: A list of key IT resources to be secured is more detailed than that which should be included in a policy.
justifications.B:
The security policy provides a broad framework of security as laid down and approved by senior
management It includes a definition of those authorized to grant access and the basis for granting
the access.
justifications.C: The identity of sensitive security assets is more detailed than that which should be included in a policy.
justifications.D:
A list of the relevant software security features is more detailed than that which should be included in a
policy.

questions.question: Which of the following is the initial step in creating a firewall policy?

options.A: A cost-benefit analysis of methods for securing the applications
options.B: Identification of network applications to be externally accessed
options.C: Identification of vulnerabilities associated with network applications to be externally accessed
options.D: Creation of an application traffic matrix showing protection methods

justifications.A:
Identifying methods to protect against identified vulnerabilities and their comparative cost-benefit
analysis is the third step.
justifications.B:
Identification of the applications required across the network should be the initial step. After
identification, depending on the physical location of these applications in the network and the
network model, the person in charge is able to understand the need for, and possible methods of,
controlling access to these applications.
justifications.C:
Having identified the externally accessed applications, the second step is to identify vulnerabilities
(weaknesses) associated with the network applications.
justifications.D:
The fourth step is to analyze the application traffic and create a matrix showing how each type of traffic
will be protected.
125

questions.question: Which of the following is an implementation risk within the process of decision support systems (DSSs)?

options.A: Management control
options.B: Semi-structured dimensions
options.C: Inability to specify purpose and usage patterns
options.D: Changes in decision processes

justifications.A: Management control is not a type of risk, but a characteristic of a decision support system (DSS).
justifications.B: Semi-structured dimensions is not a type of risk, but a characteristic of a DSS.
justifications.C:
The inability to specify purpose and usage patterns is a risk that developers need to anticipate while
implementing a DSS.
justifications.D: Changes in decision processes are not a type of risk, but a characteristic of a DSS.

questions.question:
Which of the following is MOST critical for the successful implementation and maintenance of a security
policy?

options.A: Assimilation of the framework and intent of a written security policy by all appropriate parties
options.B: Management support and approval for the implementation and maintenance of a security policy
options.C: Enforcement of security rules by providing punitive actions for any violation of security rules
options.D: Stringent implementation, monitoring and enforcing of rules by the security officer through access control

justifications.A:
Assimilation of the framework and intent of a written security policy by all levels of management
and users of the system are critical to the successful implementation and maintenance of the
security policy. If a policy is not assimilated into daily actions, it will not be effective.
justifications.B:
Management support and commitment is, no doubt, important, but for successful implementation and
maintenance of a security policy, educating the users on the importance of security is paramount.
justifications.C: Punitive actions are needed to enforce the policy but are not the key to successful implementation.
justifications.D:
The stringent implementation, monitoring and enforcing of rules by the security officer through access
control software, and provision for punitive actions for violation of security rules is important, but it is
dependent on the support and education of management and users on the importance of security.
126 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
A comprehensive and effective email policy should address the issues of email structure, policy enforcement,
monitoring and:

options.A: recovery.
options.B: retention.
options.C: rebuilding.
options.D: reuse.

justifications.A:
Email policy should address the business and legal requirements of email retention. Addressing the
retention issue in the email policy would facilitate recovery.
justifications.B:
In addition to being a good practice, laws and regulations may require an organization to keep
information that has an impact on the financial statements. The prevalence of lawsuits in which
email communication is held in the same regard as the official form of classic paper makes the
retention policy of corporate email a necessity. All email generated on an organization's hardware
is the property of the organization, and an email policy should address the retention of messages,
considering both known and unforeseen litigation. The policy should also address the destruction of
emails after a specified time to protect the nature and confidentiality of the messages themselves.
justifications.C:
Email policy should address the business and legal requirements of email retention. Addressing the
retention issue in the email policy facilitates rebuilding.
justifications.D:
Email policy should address the business and legal requirements of email retention. Reuse of email is not
a policy matter.

questions.question:
An organization is considering making a major investment to upgrade technology. Which of the following
choices is the MOST important to consider?

options.A: A cost analysis
options.B: The security risk of the current technology
options.C: Compatibility with existing systems
options.D: A risk analysis

justifications.A: The information system solution should be cost-effective, but this is not the most important aspect.
justifications.B:
The security risk of the cunent technology is one of the components of the risk analysis, and alone is not
the most important factor.
justifications.C:
Compatibility with existing systems is one consideration; however, the new system may be a major
upgrade that is not compatible with existing systems, so this is not the most important consideration.
justifications.D:
Prior to implementing new technology, an organization should perform a risk assessment, which is
then presented to business unit management for review and acceptance.
127
