questions.question:
Which of the following choices is the PRIMARY benefit of requiring a steering committee to oversee IT
investment?

options.A: To conduct a feasibility study to demonstrate IT value
options.B: To ensure that investments are made according to business requirements
options.C: To ensure that proper security controls are enforced
options.D: To ensure that a standard development methodology is implemented

justifications.A:
A steering committee may use a feasibility study in its reviews; however, it is not responsible for
performing/conducting the study.
justifications.B:
A steering committee consists of representatives from the business and IT and ensures that IT
investment is based on business objectives rather than on IT priorities.
justifications.C: The steering committee is not responsible for enforcing security controls.
justifications.D: The steering committee is not responsible for implementing development methodologies.

questions.question:
Information systems (IS) control objectives are useful to IS auditors because they provide the basis for
understanding the:

options.A: desired result or purpose of implementing specific control procedures.
options.B: best information systems (IS) security control practices relevant to a specific entity.
options.C: techniques for securing information.
options.D: security policy.

justifications.A:
An information systems (IS) control objective is defined as the statement of the desired result or
purpose to be achieved by implementing control procedures in a particular IS activity.
justifications.B:
Control objectives provide the actual objectives for implementing controls and may or may not be based
on good practices.
justifications.C:
Techniques are the means of achieving an objective, but it is more important to know the reason and
objective for the control than to understand the technique itself.
justifications.D: A security policy mandates the use of IS controls, but the controls are not used to understand policy.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important function to be performed by IT management when a service
has been outsourced?

options.A: Ensuring that invoices are paid to the provider
options.B: Participating in systems design with the provider
options.C: Renegotiating the provider's fees
options.D: Monitoring the outsourcing provider's performance

justifications.A: Payment of invoices is a finance function, which would be completed per contractual requirements.
justifications.B: Participating in systems design is a by-product of monitoring the outsourcing provider's performance.
justifications.C:
Renegotiating fees is usually a one-time activity and is not as important as monitoring the vendor's
performance.
justifications.D:
In an outsourcing environment, the enterprise is dependent on the performance of the service
provider. Therefore, it is critical that the outsourcing provider's performance is monitored to
ensure that services are delivered to the enterprise as required.

questions.question:
An organization purchased a third-party application and made significant modifications. While auditing the
development process for this critical customer-facing application, the information systems (IS) auditor noted
that the vendor has been in business for only one year. Which of the following helps to mitigate the risk
relating to continued application support?

options.A: Viability study on the vendor
options.B: Software escrow agreement
options.C: Financial evaluation of the vendor
options.D: Contractual agreement for future enhancements

justifications.A:
Although a viability study on the vendor may provide some assurance on the long-term availability of the
vendor's services to the entity, in this case, it is more important that the organization has the rights to the
source code.
justifications.B:
Considering that the vendor has been in the business for only one year, the biggest concern is
financial stability or viability of the vendor and the risk of the vendor going out of business. The
best way that this risk can be addressed is to have a software escrow agreement for the source code
of the application, which provides the entity access to the source code if the vendor goes out of
business.
justifications.C:
Considering that the vendor has been in business for only one year, financial evaluation of the vendor is
not of much value and cannot provide assurance on the long-term availability of the vendor services to the
entity. In this case, it is more important that the organization has rights to the source code.
justifications.D:
A contractual agreement, while binding, is not enforceable or only has limited value in the event of
bankruptcy.
129

questions.question: An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing an outsourcing contract of IT facilities expects it to define the:

options.A: hardware configuration.
options.B: access control software.
options.C: ownership of intellectual property (IP).
options.D: application development methodology.

justifications.A:
The hardware configuration is generally irrelevant if the functionality, availability and security can be
affected, which are specific contractual obligations.
justifications.B:
The access control software is generally irrelevant if the functionality, availability and security can be
affected, which are specific contractual obligations.
justifications.C:
The contract must specify who owns the intellectual property (IP) (i.e., information being processed
and application programs). Ownership of IP is a significant cost and is a key aspect to be defined in
an outsourcing contract
justifications.D: The development methodology should be of no real concern in an outsourcing contract.

questions.question:
While conducting an audit of a service provider, an information systems (IS) auditor observes that the service
provider has outsourced a part of the work to another provider. Because the work involves confidential
information, the IS auditor's PRIMARY concern should be that the:

options.A: requirement for securely protecting information can be compromised.
options.B: contract may be terminated because prior permission from the outsourcer was not obtained.
options.C: other service provider to whom work has been outsourced is not subject to audit.
options.D: outsourcer will approach the other service provider directly for further work.

justifications.A:
Many countries have enacted regulations to protect the confidentiality of information maintained
in their countries and/or exchanged with other countries. When a service provider outsources part
of its services to another service provider, there is a potential risk that the confidentiality of the
information will be compromised.
justifications.B:
Terminating the contract for a violation of the terms of the contract can be a concern but is not related to
ensuring the security of information.
justifications.C:
The outsourcer not being subject to an audit can be a concern but is not related to ensuring the security of
information.
justifications.D:
There is no reason why an information systems (IS) auditor should be concerned with the outsourcer
approaching the other service providers directly for further work.
130 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: A benefit of open system architecture is that it:

options.A: facilitates interoperability within different systems.
options.B: facilitates the integration of proprietary components.
options.C: is a basis for volume discounts from equipment vendors.
options.D: allows for the achievement of more economies of scale for equipment.

justifications.A:
Open systems are those for which suppliers provide components whose interfaces are defined by
public standards, thus facilitating interoperability between systems made by different vendors.
justifications.B:
Closed system components are built to proprietary standards so that other suppliers9 systems cannot
interface with existing systems.
justifications.C:
The ability to obtain volume discounts is achieved through bulk purchasing or a primary vendor, not
through open system architecture.
justifications.D:
Open systems may be less expensive than proprietary systems depending on the supplier, but the primary
benefit of open system architecture is its interoperability between vendors.

questions.question: The risk associated with electronic evidence gathering is MOST likely reduced by an email:

options.A: destruction policy.
options.B: security policy.
options.C: archive policy.
options.D: audit policy.

justifications.A:
The email retention policy includes the destruction or deletion of emails. This must be compliant with
legal requirements to retain emails.
justifications.B:
A security policy is too high-level and does not address the risk of inadequate retention of emails or the
ability to provide access to emails when required.
justifications.C:
With a policy requiring well-archived email records, access to or retrieval of specific email records
to comply with legal requirements is possible.
justifications.D: An audit policy does not address the legal requirement to provide emails as electronic evidence.

questions.question: The output of the risk management process is an input for making:

options.A: business plans.
options.B: audit charters.
options.C: security policy decisions.
options.D: software design decisions.

justifications.A: Making a business plan is not the goal of the risk management process.
justifications.B: Risk management can help create the audit plan, but not the audit charter.
justifications.C:
The risk management process is about making specific, security-related decisions, such as the level
of acceptable risk.
justifications.D:
Risk management drives the design of security controls in software but influencing security policy is
more important.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor was hired to review ebusiness security. The IS auditor's first task was to
examine each existing ebusiness application, looking for vulnerabilities. What is the IS auditor's next task?

options.A: Immediately report the risk to the chief information officer and chief executive officer.
options.B: Examine the ebusiness application in development.
options.C: Identify threats and the likelihood of occurrence.
options.D: Check the budget available for risk management.

justifications.A: The risk can only be determined after the threats, likelihood and vulnerabilities are all documented.
justifications.B:
The first step is to identify the risk levels to existing applications and then to apply those to applications in
development. Risk can only be identified after the threats and likelihood have also been determined.
justifications.C:
To determine the risk associated with ebusiness, an information systems (IS) auditor must identify
the assets, look for vulnerabilities, and then identify the threats and the likelihood of occurrence.
justifications.D:
The budget available for risk management is not relevant at this point, because the risk has not yet been
determined.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing the IT organization is MOST concerned if the IT steering
committee:

options.A: is responsible for project approval and prioritization.
options.B: is responsible for developing the long-term IT plan.
options.C: reports the status of IT projects to the board of directors.
options.D: is responsible for determining business goals.

justifications.A: The IT steering committee is responsible for project approval and prioritization.
justifications.B: The IT steering committee is responsible for oversight of the development of the long-term IT plan.
justifications.C: The IT steering committee advises the board of directors on the status of developments in IT.
justifications.D:
Determining the business goals is the responsibility of senior management and not of the IT steering
committee. IT should support business goals and be driven by the business—not the other way
around.
132

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is asked to review a contract for a vendor being considered to provide
data center services. Which is the BEST way to determine whether the terms of the contract are adhered to
after the contract is signed?

options.A: Require the vendor to provide monthly status reports.
options.B: Have periodic meetings with the client IT manager.
options.C: Conduct periodic audit reviews of the vendor.
options.D: Require that performance parameters be stated within the contract.

justifications.A:
Although providing monthly status reports may show that the vendor is meeting contract terms, without
independent verification these data may not be reliable.
justifications.B:
Having periodic meetings with the client IT manager will assist with understanding the current
relationship with the vendor, but meetings may not include vendor audit reports, status reports and other
information that a periodic audit review would take into consideration.
justifications.C:
Conducting periodic reviews of the vendor ensures that the agreements within the contract are
completed in a satisfactory manner. Without future audit reviews after the contract is signed,
service level agreements and the clienfs requirements for security controls may become less of a
focus for the vendor, and the results may slip. Periodic audit reviews allow the client to look at the
vendor's current state to ensure that the vendor is one with which they want to continue to work.
justifications.D:
Requiring that performance parameters be stated within the contract is important, but only if periodic
reviews are performed to determine that performance parameters are met.

questions.question: Which of the following inputs adds the MOST value to the strategic IT initiative decision-making process?

options.A: Maturity of the project management process
options.B: Regulatory environment
options.C: Past audit findings
options.D: IT project portfolio analysis

justifications.A:
The maturity of the project management process is more important with respect to managing the day-to-
day operations of IT versus performing strategic planning.
justifications.B:
Regulatory requirements may drive investment in certain technologies and initiatives; however, having to
meet regulatory requirements is not typically the main focus of the IT and business strategy.
justifications.C:
Past audit findings may drive investment in certain technologies and initiatives; however, having to
remediate past audit findings is not the main focus of the IT and business strategy.
justifications.D:
Portfolio analysis provides the best input into the decision-making process relating to planning
strategic IT initiatives. An analysis of the IT portfolio provides comparable information of planned
initiatives, projects and ongoing IT services, which allows the IT strategy to be aligned with the
business strategy.
133

questions.question: The access control policy should be reviewed by the information systems (IS) auditor to:

options.A: prevent unauthorized disclosure of organizational data.
options.B: ensure that organizational objectives for separation of duties are met.
options.C: minimize the impact of an incident.
options.D: ensure the continuity of business after any disaster.

justifications.A:
The principles of confidentiality prevent the unauthorized disclosure of organizational data of an
organization, not the access control policy.
justifications.B:
The organizational access control policy ensures that organizational objectives for separation of
duties are met, preventing fraud or errors and meeting policy requirements for minimizing the risk
of unauthorized access.
justifications.C: The access control policy helps to minimize error, but it does not minimize the impact of an incident.
justifications.D: The business continuity policy is concerned with the continuity of business, not the access control policy.

questions.question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY objective of an IT performance measurement process?

options.A: Minimize errors
options.B: Gather performance data
options.C: Establish performance baselines
options.D: Optimize performance

justifications.A: Minimizing errors is an aspect of performance but not the primary objective of performance management.
justifications.B:
Gathering performance data is necessary to measure IT performance but is not the objective of the
process.
justifications.C:
The performance measurement process compares actual performance with baselines but is not the
objective of the process.
justifications.D:
An IT performance measurement process can be used to optimize performance, measure and
manage products/services, assure accountability, and make budget decisions.
134 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: As an outcome of information security governance, strategic alignment provides:

options.A: security requirements driven by enterprise requirements.
options.B: baseline security following good practices.
options.C: institutionalized and commoditized solutions.
options.D: an understanding of risk exposure.

justifications.A:
Information security governance, when properly implemented, should provide four basic outcomes:
strategic alignment, value delivery, risk management and performance measurement. Strategic
alignment provides input for security requirements driven by enterprise requirements.
justifications.B:
Strategic alignment ensures that security aligns with business goals. Providing a standard set of security
practices (i.e., baseline security following good practices or institutionalized and commoditized solutions)
is a part of value delivery.
justifications.C:
Value delivery addresses the effectiveness and efficiency of solutions but is not a result of strategic
alignment.
justifications.D:
Risk management is a primary goal of IT governance, but strategic alignment is not focused on
understanding risk exposure.

questions.question:
Which of the following should be of GREATEST concern to an information systems (IS) auditor when
reviewing an information security policy? The policy:

options.A: is driven by an IT departmenfs objectives.
options.B: is published, but users are not required to read the policy.
options.C: does not include information security procedures.
options.D: has not been updated in over a year.

justifications.A:
Business objectives drive the information security policy, and the information security policy drives
the selection of IT department objectives. A policy driven by IT objectives is at risk of not being
aligned with business goals.
justifications.B:
Policies should be written so that users can understand each policy, and employees should be able to
easily access the policies. The fact that users have not read the policy is not the greatest concern because
they still may be compliant with the policy.
justifications.C:
Policies should not contain procedures. Procedures are established to assist with policy implementation
and compliance.
justifications.D:
Policies should be reviewed annually, but they might not necessarily be updated annually unless there are
significant changes in the environment, such as new laws, rules or regulations.
135
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition

questions.question: Which of the following IT governance good practices improves strategic alignment?

options.A: Supplier and partner risk is managed.
options.B: A knowledge base of customers, products, markets and processes is in place.
options.C: A structure is provided that facilitates the creation and sharing of business information.
options.D: Top management mediates between the imperatives of business and technology.

justifications.A: Managing supplier and partner risk is a risk management good practice but not a strategic function.
justifications.B:
A knowledge base of customers, products, markets and processes being in place is an IT value delivery
good practice but does not ensure strategic alignment.
justifications.C:
An infrastructure that facilitates the creation and sharing of business information is an IT value delivery
and risk management good practice but is not as effective as top management involvement in business
and technology alignment.
justifications.D:
Top management mediating between the imperatives of business and technology is an IT strategic
alignment good practice.

questions.question: Effective IT governance requires organizational structures and processes to ensure that:

options.A: risk is maintained at a level acceptable for IT management.
options.B: the business strategy is derived from an IT strategy.
options.C: IT governance is separate and distinct from overall governance.
options.D: the IT strategy extends the organization strategies and objectives.

justifications.A: Risk acceptance levels are set by senior management, not by IT management.
justifications.B: The business strategy drives the IT strategy, not the opposite direction.
justifications.C:
IT governance is not an isolated discipline; it must become an integral part of overall enterprise
governance.
justifications.D:
Effective IT governance requires that board and executive management extend governance to
IT and provide the leadership, organizational structures and processes that ensure that the
organization IT sustains and extends the organization strategies and objectives, and that the
strategy is aligned with business strategy.
136

questions.question: Assessing IT risk is BEST achieved by:

options.A: evaluating threats and vulnerabilities that are associated with existing IT assets and IT projects.
options.B: using the organization's past actual loss experience to determine current exposure.
options.C: reviewing published loss statistics from comparable organizations.
options.D: reviewing IT control weaknesses identified in audit reports.

justifications.A:
To assess IT risk, threats and vulnerabilities need to be evaluated using qualitative or quantitative
risk assessment approaches.
justifications.B:
Basing an assessment on past losses does not adequately reflect new threats or inevitable changes to the
organization's IT assets, projects, controls and strategic environment. There are also likely to be problems
with the scope and quality of the loss data available to be assessed.
justifications.C:
Comparable organizations have differences in their IT assets, control environment and strategic
circumstances. Therefore, their loss experience cannot be used to directly assess organizational IT risk.
justifications.D:
Control weaknesses identified during audits are relevant in assessing threat exposure, and further analysis
may be needed to assess threat probability. Depending on the scope of the audit coverage, it is possible
that not all of the critical IT assets and projects will have recently been audited, and there may not be a
sufficient assessment of strategic IT risk.

questions.question:
When separation of duties concerns exist between IT support staff and end users, what is a suitable
compensating control?

options.A: Restricting physical access to computing equipment
options.B: Reviewing transaction and application logs
options.C: Performing background checks prior to hiring IT staff
options.D: Locking user sessions after a specified period of inactivity

justifications.A:
IT support staff usually require physical access to computing equipment to perform their job functions. It
would not be reasonable to remove this access.
justifications.B:
Reviewing transaction and application logs directly addresses the threat posed by poor separation
of duties. The review is a means of detecting inappropriate behavior and discourages abuse, because
people who may otherwise be tempted to exploit the situation are aware of the likelihood of being
caught.
justifications.C:
Performing background checks is a useful control to ensure that IT staff are trustworthy and competent
but does not directly address the lack of an optimal separation of duties.
justifications.D:
Locking user sessions after a specified period of inactivity acts to prevent unauthorized users from
gaining system access, but the issue of a lack of separation of duties is more the misuse (deliberately or
inadvertently) of access privileges that have officially been granted.
137

questions.question: A top-down approach to the development of operational policies helps to ensure that:

options.A: they are consistent across the organization.
options.B: they are implemented as a part of risk assessment.
options.C: there is compliance with all policies.
options.D: they are reviewed periodically.

justifications.A:
Deriving lower-level policies from corporate policies (a top-down approach) aids in ensuring
consistency across the organization and consistency with other policies.
justifications.B:
Policies should be influenced by risk assessment, but the primary reason for a top-down approach is to
ensure that the policies are consistent across the organization.
justifications.C: A top-down approach, alone, does not ensure compliance.
justifications.D: A top-down approach, alone, does not ensure that policies are reviewed.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing an organization that uses cross-training practices should assess
the risk of:

options.A: dependency on a single person.
options.B: inadequate succession planning.
options.C: one person knowing all parts of a system.
options.D: a disruption of operations.

justifications.A: Cross-training helps decrease dependence on a single person.
justifications.B: Cross-training assists in succession planning.
justifications.C:
Cross-training is a process of training more than one individual to perform a specific job or
procedure. However, before using this approach, it is prudent to assess the risk of any person
knowing all parts of a system and the related potential exposures related to abuse of privilege.
justifications.D:
Cross-training provides for the backup of personnel in the event of an absence and, thereby, provides for
the continuity of operations.
138

questions.question:
Which of the following should be of PRIMARY concern to an information systems (IS) auditor reviewing the
management of external IT service providers?

options.A: Minimizing costs for the services provided
options.B: Prohibiting the provider from subcontracting services
options.C: Evaluating the process for transferring knowledge to the IT department
options.D: Determining if the services were provided as contracted

justifications.A:
Minimizing costs, if applicable and achievable (depending on the customer's need), is traditionally not
part of an information systems (IS) auditor's job. This work is normally done by aline management
function within the IT department. Furthermore, during an audit, it is too late to minimize the costs for
existing provider arrangements.
justifications.B:
Subcontracting providers can be a concern but is not the primary concern. This issue should be addressed
in the contract.
justifications.C:
Transferring knowledge to the internal IT department might be desirable under certain circumstances
but should not be the primary concern of an IS auditor when auditing IT service providers and the
management thereof.
justifications.D:
From an IS auditor's perspective, the primary objective of auditing the management of service
providers should be to determine if the services that were requested were provided in a way that is
acceptable, seamless and in line with contractual agreements.

questions.question:
Which of the following MOST likely indicates that a customer data warehouse should remain in-house rather
than be outsourced to an offshore operation?

options.A: Time-zone differences can impede communications between IT teams.
options.B: Telecommunications cost can be much higher in the first year.
options.C: Privacy laws can prevent cross-border flow of information.
options.D: Software development may require more detailed specifications.

justifications.A: Time-zone differences are usually manageable issues for outsourcing solutions.
justifications.B:
Higher telecommunications costs are a part of the cost-benefit analysis and not usually a reason to retain
data in-house.
justifications.C:
Privacy laws prohibiting the cross-border flow of personally identifiable information make it
impossible to locate a data warehouse containing customer information in another country.
justifications.D:
Software development typically requires more detailed specifications when dealing with offshore
operations, but that is not a factor that should prohibit the outsourcing solution.
139

questions.question:
When reviewing an organization's approved software product list, which of the following is the MOST
important thing to verify?

options.A: The risk associated with the use of the products is periodically assessed.
options.B: The latest version of software is listed for each product.
options.C: Due to licensing issues, the list does not contain open-source software.
options.D: After-hours support is offered.

justifications.A:
Because the business conditions surrounding vendors may change, it is important for an
organization to conduct periodic risk assessments of the vendor software list. This may be best
incorporated into the IT risk management process.
justifications.B: The organization may not be using the latest version of a product.
justifications.C: The list may contain open-source software depending on the business requirements and associated risk.
justifications.D:
Support may be provided internally or externally, and technical support should be arranged depending on
the criticality of the software.

questions.question:
When reviewing the development of information security policies, the PRIMARY focus of an information
systems (IS) auditor should be on assuring that these policies:

options.A: are aligned with globally accepted industry good practices.
options.B: are approved by the board of directors and senior management.
options.C: strike a balance between business and security requirements.
options.D: provide direction for implementing security procedures.

justifications.A:
An organization is not required to base its IT policies on industry good practices. Policies must be based
on the culture and business requirements of the organization.
justifications.B:
It is essential that policies be approved; however, that is not the primary fbcus during the development of
the policies.
justifications.C:
Because information security policies must be aligned with an organization's business and security
objectives, this is the primary focus of the information systems (IS) auditor when reviewing the
development of information security policies.
justifications.D:
Policies cannot provide direction if they are not aligned with business requirements.
140

questions.question:
On which of the following factors should an information systems (IS) auditor PRIMARILY focus when
determining the appropriate level of protection for an information asset?

options.A: Results of a risk assessment
options.B: Relative value to the business
options.C: Results of a vulnerability assessment
options.D: Cost of security controls

justifications.A:
The appropriate level of protection for an asset is determined based on the risk associated with
the asset The results of the risk assessment are, therefore, the primary information that the
information systems (IS) auditor should review.
justifications.B:
The relative value of an asset to the business is one element considered in the risk assessment; this alone
does not determine the level of protection required.
justifications.C:
The results of a vulnerability assessment are useful when creating the risk assessment; however, this is not
the primary focus.
justifications.D:
The cost of security controls is not a primary factor to consider because the expenditures on these controls
are determined by the value of the information assets being protected.

questions.question:
From an IT governance perspective, what is the PRIMARY responsibility of the board of directors? To
ensure that the IT strategy:

options.A: is cost-effective.
options.B: is forward thinking and innovative.
options.C: is aligned with the business strategy.
options.D: has the appropriate priority level assigned.

justifications.A:
The IT strategy should be cost-effective, but it must align with the business strategy for the strategy to be
effective.
justifications.B:
The IT strategy should be forward-thinking and innovative, but it must align with the business strategy to
be effective.
justifications.C:
The board of directors is responsible for ensuring that the IT strategy is aligned with the business
strategy.
justifications.D:
The IT strategy should be appropriately prioritized; however, it must align with the business strategy first
and then it will be prioritized.
141

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST important element for the successful implementation of IT governance?

options.A: Implementing an IT scorecard
options.B: Identifying organizational strategies
options.C: Performing a risk assessment
options.D: Creating a formal security policy

justifications.A:
A scorecard is an excellent tool to implement a program based on good governance, but the most
important factor in implementing governance is alignment with organizational strategies.
justifications.B:
The key objective of an IT governance program is to support the business; therefore, the
identification of organizational strategies is necessary to ensure alignment between IT and
corporate governance. Without identification of organizational strategies, the remaining choices—
even if implemented—would be ineffective.
justifications.C:
A risk assessment is important to ensure that the security program is based on areas of highest risk, but
risk assessment must be based on organizational strategies.
justifications.D:
A policy is a key part of security program implementation, but even the policy must be based on
organizational strategies.

questions.question:
To aid management in achieving IT and business alignment, an information systems (IS) auditor should
recommend the use of:

options.A: control self-assessments (CSAs).
options.B: a business impact analysis (BIA).
options.C: an IT balanced scorecard (BSC).
options.D: business process reengineering.

justifications.A:
Control self-assessments (CSAs) are used to improve monitoring of security controls but are not used to
align IT with organizational objectives.
justifications.B:
A business impact analysis (BIA) is used to calculate the impact on the business in the event of an
incident that affects business operations, but it is not used to align IT with organizational objectives.
justifications.C:
An IT balanced scorecard (BSC) provides the bridge between IT objectives and business
objectives by supplementing the traditional financial evaluation with measures to evaluate customer
satisfaction, internal processes and the ability to innovate.
justifications.D:
Business process reengineering is an excellent tool to review and improve business processes but is not
focused on aligning IT with organizational objectives.
142

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST reference for an information systems (IS) auditor to determine a vendor's
ability to meet service level agreement requirements for a critical IT security service?

options.A: Compliance with the master contract
options.B: Agreed-on key performance indicators (KPIs)
options.C: Results of business continuity tests
options.D: Results of independent audit reports

justifications.A:
The master contract typically includes terms, conditions and costs but does not typically include service
levels.
justifications.B:
Key performance indicators (KPIs) are metrics that allow for a means to measure performance.
Service level agreements (SLAs) are statements related to expected service levels. For example, an
Internet service provider (ISP) may guarantee that their service will be available 99.99 percent of
the time.
justifications.C:
If applicable to the service, results of business continuity tests are typically included as part of the due
diligence review.
justifications.D:
Independent audits report on the financial condition of an organization or the control environment.
Reviewing audit reports is typically part of the due diligence review. Even audits must be performed
against a set of standards or metrics to validate compliance.

questions.question:
To address the risk of operations staff's failure to perform the daily backup, management requires that the
systems administrator sign off on the daily backup. This is an example of risk:

options.A: avoidance.
options.B: transfer.
options.C: mitigation.
options.D: acceptance.

justifications.A:
Risk avoidance is a strategy that provides for not implementing certain activities or processes that would
incur risk.
justifications.B: Risk transfer is the strategy that provides for sharing risk with partners or purchasing insurance coverage.
justifications.C:
Risk mitigation is the strategy that provides for the definition and implementation of controls to
address the risk described. By requiring the system's administrator to sign off on the completion of
the backups, this is an administrative control that can be validated for compliance.
justifications.D:
Risk acceptance is a strategy that provides for formal acknowledgment of the existence of a risk but not
taking any action to reduce the risk, and the monitoring of that risk.
143

questions.question:
A poor choice of passwords and unencrypted data transmissions over unprotected communications lines are
examples of:

options.A: vulnerabilities.
options.B: threats.
options.C: probabilities.
options.D: impacts.

justifications.A:
Vulnerabilities represent weaknesses of information resources that may be exploited by a threat
Because these are weaknesses that can be addressed by the security specialist, they are examples of
vulnerabilities.
justifications.B:
Threats are circumstances or events with the potential to cause harm to information resources. Threats are
usually outside the control of the security specialist.
justifications.C: Probabilities represent the likelihood of the occurrence of a threat.
justifications.D: Impacts represent the outcome or result of a threat exploiting a vulnerability.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is assigned to review IT structures and activities recently outsourced to
various providers. Which of the following should the IS auditor determine FIRST?

options.A: An audit clause is present in all contracts.
options.B:
The service level agreement (SLA) of each contract is substantiated by appropriate key performance
indicators (KPIs).
options.C: The contractual warranties of the providers support the business needs of the organization.
options.D: At contract termination, support is guaranteed by each outsourcer for new outsourcers.

justifications.A:
All choices are important, but the first step is to ensure that the contracts support the business—only then
can an audit process be valuable.
justifications.B:
All service level agreements (SLAs) should be measurable and reinforced through key performance
indicators (KPIs)—but the first step is to ensure that the SLAs are aligned with business requirements.
justifications.C:
The primary requirement is for the services provided by the outsource supplier to meet the needs of
the business.
justifications.D:
Having appropriate controls in place for contract termination are important, but first the information
systems (IS) auditor must be focused on the requirement of the supplier to meet business needs.
144

questions.question:
To gain an understanding of the effectiveness of an organization's planning and management of investments in
IT assets, an information systems (IS) auditor should review the:

options.A: enterprise data model.
options.B: IT balanced scorecard (BSC).
options.C: IT organizational structure.
options.D: historical financial statements.

justifications.A:
An enterprise data model is a document defining the data structure of an organization and how data
interrelate. The model is useful, but it does not provide information on investments in IT assets.
justifications.B:
The IT balanced scorecard (BSC) is a tool that provides the bridge between IT objectives and
business objectives by supplementing the traditional financial evaluation with measures to evaluate
customer satisfaction, internal processes and the ability to innovate. In this way, the auditor can
measure the success of the IT investment and strategy.
justifications.C:
The IT organizational structure provides an overview of the functional and reporting relationships in an IT
entity but does not ensure effectiveness of IT investment.
justifications.D:
Historical financial statements do not provide information about planning and lack sufficient detail to
enable one to fully understand managemenfs activities regarding IT assets. Past costs do not necessarily
reflect value, and assets such as data are not represented in the books of accounts.

questions.question:
Regarding the outsourcing of IT services, which of the following conditions should be of GREATEST
concern to an information systems (IS) auditor?

options.A: Core activities that provide a differentiated advantage to the organization have been outsourced.
options.B: Periodic renegotiation is not specified in the outsourcing contract.
options.C: The outsourcing contract fails to cover every action required by the business.
options.D: Similar activities are outsourced to more than one vendor.

justifications.A:
An organization's core activities generally should not be outsourced because they are what the
organization does best; an information systems (IS) auditor observing that condition should be
concerned.
justifications.B:
An IS auditor should not be concerned about periodic renegotiation in the outsourcing contract because
that is dependent on the terms of the contract.
justifications.C:
Outsourcing contracts cannot be expected to cover every action and detail expected of the parties involved
but should cover business requirements.
justifications.D:
Multisourcing is an acceptable way to reduce risk associated with a single point of failure.
145

questions.question: How would data analytics BEST help in information systems (IS) auditing?

options.A: Ensuring that the information systems (IS) auditing process is completed on time and accurate
options.B: Automating auditing process and examining a large quantity of data
options.C: Improving auditing quality and decreasing human intervention
options.D: Detecting potential issues with the IS controls of an organization

justifications.A:
Like any other project, information systems (IS) auditing should be completed as per the constraints of
scope, time and cost, and should be accurate to be able to assess the objectives and effectiveness of IS
controls.
justifications.B:
Automating the auditing process can give time for auditors to fbcus on critical aspects of their audit
objectives, like reducing risk. Examining appropriate and sufficient evidence helps to evaluate the
objectives and effectiveness of IS controls.
justifications.C:
Accuracy, collecting authentic information for evidence analysis and reducing human errors in auditing
helps to judge whether IS controls are effective and function as expected.
justifications.D:
IS auditing, being a risk-based process, should be able to detect the potential issues within IS
controls and conclude whether those controls are well-designed and effective.

questions.question: The PRIMARY control purpose of required vacations or job rotations is to:

options.A: allow cross-training for development.
options.B: help preserve employee morale.
options.C: detect improper or illegal employee acts.
options.D: provide a competitive employee benefit.

justifications.A:
Although cross-training is a good practice for business continuity, it is not achieved through mandatory
vacations.
justifications.B:
It is a good practice to maintain good employee morale, but this is not a primary reason to have a required
vacation policy.
justifications.C:
The practice of having another individual perform a job function is a control used to detect possible
irregularities or fraud.
justifications.D:
Vacation time is a competitive benefit, but that is not a control.
146 CIS A ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
When reviewing the IT strategic planning process, an information systems (IS) auditor should ensure that the
plan:

options.A: incorporates state-of-the-art technology.
options.B: addresses the required operational controls.
options.C: articulates the IT mission and vision.
options.D: specifies project management practices.

justifications.A:
The plan does not need to address state-oMhe-art technology; the decision to implement new technology
is dependent on the approach to risk and management strategy.
justifications.B:
The plan does not need to address operational controls because those are too granular for strategic
planning.
justifications.C: The IT strategic plan must include a clear articulation of the IT mission and vision.
justifications.D:
The plan should be implemented with proper project management, but the plan does not need to address
project management practices.

questions.question:
A small organization has only one database administrator (DBA) and one system administrator. The DBA
has root access to the UNIX server, which hosts the database application. How should separation of duties be
enforced in this scenario?

options.A: Hire a second DBA and split the duties between the two individuals.
options.B: Remove the DBA's root access on all UNIX servers.
options.C: Ensure that all actions of the DBA are logged and that all logs are backed up to removable media.
options.D: Ensure that database logs are forwarded to a UNIX server where the DBA does not have root access.

justifications.A: Hiring additional staff is a costly way to ensure separation of duties.
justifications.B: The database administrator (DBA) needs root access to the database servers to install upgrades or patches.
justifications.C: The administrator can modify or erase logs prior to the media backup event.
justifications.D:
By creating logs that the DBA cannot erase or modify, separation of duties is enforced.
147

questions.question:
Which of the following does an information systems (IS) auditor FIRST reference when performing an IS
audit?

options.A: Implemented procedures
options.B: Approved policies
options.C: Internal standards
options.D: Documented practices

justifications.A: Procedures are implemented in accordance with policy.
justifications.B:
Policies are high-level documents that represent the corporate philosophy of an organization.
Internal standards, procedures and practices are subordinate to policy.
justifications.C: Standards are subordinate to policy.
justifications.D:
Practices are subordinate to policy.
148

questions.question:
An enterprise selected a vendor to develop and implement a new software system. To ensure that the
enterprise's investment in software is protected, which of the following security clauses is MOST important
to include in the master services agreement?

options.A: Limitation of liability
options.B: Service level requirements
options.C: Software escrow
options.D: Version control

justifications.A:
A limitation of liability clause protects the financial exposure of the organization but not its software
investment.
justifications.B:
Service level requirements specify financial penalties for not meeting standards, but these do not address
issues of vendor insolvency.
justifications.C:
Software escrow clauses in a contract ensure that the software source code will still be available to
the organization in the event of a vendor issue, such as insolvency and copyright issues.
justifications.D: Version control is related to the software development life cycle and not the software investment.

questions.question: When implementing an IT governance framework in an organization, the MOST important objective is:

options.A: IT alignment with the business.
options.B: accountability.
options.C: value realization with IT.
options.D: enhancing the return on IT investments.

justifications.A:
The goals of IT governance are to improve IT performance, deliver optimum business value and
ensure regulatory compliance. The key practice in support of these goals is the strategic alignment
of IT with the business. To achieve alignment, all other choices need to be tied to business practices
and strategies.
justifications.B:
Accountability is important, but the most important objective of IT governance is to ensure that IT
investment and oversight are aligned with business requirements.
justifications.C:
IT must demonstrate value to the organization, but this value is dependent on the ability of IT to align
with, and support, business requirements.
justifications.D:
Enhancing return is a requirement of the IT governance framework, but this requirement is only
demonstrated through aligning IT with business requirements.
149

questions.question: Measures of security risk should:

options.A: address all of the network risk.
options.B: be tracked over time against the IT strategic plan.
options.C: consider the entire IT environment.
options.D: result in the identification of vulnerability tolerances.

justifications.A:
Measures of security risk should not be limited to network risk, but rather focus on those areas with the
highest criticality so that maximum risk reduction is achieved at the lowest possible cost.
justifications.B:
IT strategic plans are not granular enough to provide appropriate measures. Objective metrics must be
tracked over time against measurable goals; thus, the management of risk is enhanced by comparing
today's results against results from last week, last month and last quarter. Risk measures will profile assets
on a network to objectively measure vulnerability risk.
justifications.C: When assessing IT security risk, it is important to consider the entire IT environment.
justifications.D: Measures of security risk do not identify tolerances.

questions.question: The ultimate purpose of IT governance is to:

options.A: encourage optimal use of IT.
options.B: reduce IT costs.
options.C: decentralize IT resources across the organization.
options.D: centralize control of IT.

justifications.A:
The purpose of IT governance is to direct the IT endeavors to ensure that IT performance meets the
objectives of aligning IT with the enterprise's objectives and the realization of promised benefits.
Thus, generating business value and mitigating the risks associated with IT, results in the optimal
use of IT.
justifications.B: Reducing IT costs may not be the best IT governance outcome for an enterprise.
justifications.C:
Decentralizing IT resources across the organization is not always desired, although it may be desired in a
decentralized environment.
justifications.D:
Centralizing control of IT is not always desired. An example of where it might be desired is an enterprise
wanting a single point of customer contact.
150

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important for an information systems (IS) auditor to consider when
reviewing a service level agreement with an external IT service provider?

options.A: Payment terms
options.B: Uptime guarantee
options.C: Indemnification clause
options.D: Default resolution

justifications.A:
Payment terms are typically included in the master agreement rather than in the service level agreement
(SLA).
justifications.B:
The most important element of an SLA is the measurable terms of performance, such as uptime
agreements.
justifications.C: The indemnification clause is typically included in the master agreement rather than in the SLA.
justifications.D:
The default resolution only applies in case of a default of the SLA; therefore, it is more important to
review the performance conditions of the SLA.

questions.question: The PRIMARY objective of implementing corporate governance is to:

options.A: provide strategic direction.
options.B: control business operations.
options.C: align IT with business.
options.D: implement good practices.

justifications.A:
Corporate governance is a set of management practices to provide strategic direction to the
organization as a whole, thereby ensuring that goals are achievable, risk is properly addressed and
organizational resources are properly used. Hence, the primary objective of corporate governance
is to provide strategic direction.
justifications.B: Business operations are directed and controlled based on the strategic direction.
justifications.C:
Corporate governance applies strategic planning, monitoring and accountability to the entire organization,
not just to IT.
justifications.D:
Governance is applied through the use of good practices, but this is not the objective of corporate
governance.
151

questions.question: Which of the following should be considered FIRST when implementing a risk management program?

options.A: An understanding of the organization's threat, vulnerability and risk profile
options.B: An understanding of the risk exposures and the potential consequences of compromise
options.C: A determination of risk management priorities that are based on potential consequences
options.D: A risk mitigation strategy sufficient to keep risk consequences at an acceptable level

justifications.A:
Implementing risk management~ ne of the outcomes of effective information security governance
一requires a collective understanding of the organization's threat, vulnerability and risk profile as a
first step.
justifications.B:
An understanding of risk exposure and potential consequences of compromise can be determined only
after there is an understanding of the organization's threat, vulnerability and risk profile.
justifications.C:
Risk management priorities that are based on potential consequences (the magnitude of the impact) and
the probability of occurrence can only be developed after the organization's threat, vulnerability and risk
profile is determined and evaluated.
justifications.D:
Risk mitigation priorities are based on the risk profile, risk acceptance levels and potential mitigating
controls. These elements provide a basis for the formulation of strategies for risk mitigation sufficient
to keep the consequences from risk at an acceptable level. This forms part of the last step in the risk
assessment process.

questions.question: In the context of effective information security governance, the PRIMARY objective of value delivery is to:

options.A: optimize security investments in support of business objectives.
options.B: implement a standard set of security practices.
options.C: institute a standards-based solution.
options.D: implement a continuous improvement culture.

justifications.A:
Information security governance provides strategic direction for security activities and ensures
that business objectives are achieved. Therefore, in the context of effective information security
governance, value delivery is implemented to ensure optimization of security investments in support
of business objectives.
justifications.B:
The tools and techniques for implementing value delivery include implementation of a standard set of
security practices; however, implementation of standards is a means to achieve the objective of supporting
value delivery, not the objective itself
justifications.C:
Value delivery may be supported with standards-based solutions, but the use of standards-based solutions
is not the goal of value delivery.
justifications.D:
Continuous improvement culture in relation to a security program is a process, not an objective.
152

questions.question: A driver of IT governance, transparency of IT cost, value and risk is primarily achieved through:

options.A: performance measurement.
options.B: strategic alignment.
options.C: value delivery.
options.D: resource management.

justifications.A:
Performance measurement includes setting and monitoring measurable objectives that the IT
processes need to achieve to deliver (process outcome), and how they deliver it (process capability
and performance). Transparency is primarily achieved through performance measurement because
it provides information to the stakeholders on how well the enterprise is performing when
compared to objectives.
justifications.B: Strategic alignment primarily focuses on ensuring linkage of business and IT plans, not on transparency.
justifications.C:
Value delivery is about executing the value proposition throughout the delivery cycle. Value delivery
ensures that IT investments deliver on promised values but does not ensure transparency of investment.
justifications.D:
Resource management is about the optimal investment in and proper management of critical IT resources
but does not ensure transparency of IT investments.

questions.question:
Which of the following should be the MOST important consideration when deciding on areas of priority for
IT governance implementations?

options.A: Process maturity
options.B: Performance indicators
options.C: Business risk
options.D: Assurance reports

justifications.A:
The level of process maturity evolves as the implementation of the IT governance program occurs and
may feed into the decision-making process. Those areas that represent real risk to the business should be
given priority.
justifications.B:
The level of process performance demonstrates the effectiveness of the program but is not the means to
establish priorities for governance. Those areas that represent real risk to the business should be given
priority.
justifications.C:
Priority should be given to those business areas of the enterprise operations that face real risk based
on the probability of occurrence and the magnitude of the impact
justifications.D:
Assurance (audit) reports provide assurance of the effectiveness of the implementation of governance but
do not determine the priorities for a program. Those areas that represent real risk to the business should be
given priority.
153

questions.question: Responsibility for the governance of IT should rest with the:

options.A: IT strategy committee.
options.B: chief information officer (CIO).
options.C: audit committee.
options.D: board of directors.

justifications.A:
The IT strategy committee plays a significant role in the successful implementation of IT governance
within an organization, but the ultimate responsibility resides with the board of directors.
justifications.B:
The chief information officer (CIO) plays a significant role in the successful implementation of IT
governance within an organization, but the ultimate responsibility resides with the board of directors.
justifications.C:
The audit committee plays a significant role in monitoring and overseeing the successful implementation
of IT governance within an organization, but the ultimate responsibility resides with the board of
directors.
justifications.D:
Governance is the set of responsibilities and practices exercised by the board and executive
management with the goal of providing strategic direction, ensuring that objectives are achieved,
ascertaining that risk is managed appropriately and verifying that the enterprise's resources are
used responsibly.

questions.question: Which of the following is normally a responsibility of the chief information security officer (CISO)?

options.A: Periodically reviewing and evaluating the security policy
options.B: Executing user application and software testing and evaluation
options.C: Granting and revoking user access to IT resources
options.D: Approving access to data and applications

justifications.A:
The role of the chief information security officer (CISO) is to ensure that the corporate security
policy and controls are adequate to prevent unauthorized access to the enterprise assets, including
data, programs and equipment
justifications.B:
User application and other software testing and evaluation normally are the responsibility of the staff
assigned to development and maintenance.
justifications.C:
Granting and revoking access to IT resources is usually a function of system, network or database
administrators.
justifications.D:
Approval of access to data and applications is the duty of the data or application owner.
154 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manuall3th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: When developing a formal enterprise security program, the MOST critical success factor (CSF) is the:

options.A: establishment of a review board.
options.B: creation of a security unit.
options.C: effective support of an executive sponsor.
options.D: selection of a security process owner.

justifications.A: Establishment of a review board is not effective without visible sponsorship of top management.
justifications.B: The creation of a security unit is not effective without visible sponsorship of top management.
justifications.C:
The executive sponsor is in charge of supporting the organization's strategic security program and
aids in directing the organization's overall security management activities. Therefore, support by
the executive level of management is the most critical success factor (CSF).
justifications.D: The selection of a security process owner is not effective without visible sponsorship of top management.

questions.question: When reviewing an organization's strategic IT plan, an information systems (IS) auditor should expect to find:

options.A: an assessment of the fit of the organization's application portfolio with business objectives.
options.B: actions to reduce hardware procurement cost.
options.C: a listing of approved suppliers of IT contract resources.
options.D: a description of the technical architecture for the organization's network perimeter security.

justifications.A:
An assessment of how well an organization^ application portfolio supports the organization^
business objectives is a key component of the overall IT strategic planning process. This
assessment drives the demand side of IT planning and should convert into a set of strategic
IT intentions. Further assessment can then be made of how well the overall IT organization,
encompassing applications, infrastructure, services, management processes, etc. can support the
business objectives. The purpose of an IT strategic plan is to set out how IT will be used to achieve
or support an organization^ business objectives.
justifications.B:
Operational efficiency initiatives, including cost reduction of purchasing and maintenance activities of
systems, belong to tactical planning, not strategic planning.
justifications.C: A list of approved suppliers of IT contract resources is a tactical, rather than a strategic, concern.
justifications.D:
An IT strategic plan does not normally include detail of a specific technical architecture.
155

questions.question: When developing a security architecture, which of the following steps should be executed FIRST?

options.A: Developing security procedures
options.B: Defining a security policy
options.C: Specifying an access control methodology
options.D: Defining roles and responsibilities

justifications.A:
Policy is used to provide direction for procedures, standards and baselines. Therefore, developing security
procedures should be executed only after defining a security policy.
justifications.B:
Defining a security policy for information and related technology is the first step toward building
a security architecture. A security policy communicates a coherent security standard to users,
management and technical staff Security policies often set the stage in terms of the tools and
procedures that are needed for an organization.
justifications.C:
Specifying an access control methodology is an implementation concern and should be executed only
after defining a security policy.
justifications.D: Defining roles and responsibilities should be executed only after defining a security policy.

questions.question:
Which of the following should an information systems (IS) auditor recommend to BEST enforce alignment of
an IT project portfolio with strategic organizational priorities?

options.A: Define a balanced scorecard (BSC) for measuring performance.
options.B: Consider user satisfaction in the key performance indicators (KPIs).
options.C: Select projects according to business benefits and risk.
options.D: Modify the yearly process of defining the project portfolio.

justifications.A:
Measures such as a balanced scorecard (BSC) are helpful, but do not guarantee that the projects are
aligned with business strategy.
justifications.B:
Key performance indicators (KPIs)are helpful to monitor and measure IT performance, but they do not
guarantee that the projects are aligned with business strategy.
justifications.C:
Prioritization of projects on the basis of their expected benefit(s) to business, and the related risk,
is the best measure for achieving alignment of the project portfolio to an organization's strategic
priorities.
justifications.D:
Modifying the yearly process of the project portfolio definition might improve the situation, but only if
the portfolio definition process is closely tied to organizational strategies.
156 C!SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13比 Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The PRIMARY benefit of implementing a security program as part of a security governance framework is
the:

options.A: alignment of the IT activities with information systems (IS) audit recommendations.
options.B: enforcement of the management of security risk.
options.C: implementation of the chief information security officer's recommendations.
options.D: reduction of the cost for IT security.

justifications.A:
Recommendations of the information systems (IS) auditor are usually addressed as value addition within
a security program, but that would not be the primary benefit of implementing a security program.
justifications.B:
The primary benefit of implementing a security program is managemenfs assessment of risk and
its mitigation to an appropriate level, and monitoring of the residual risk.
justifications.C:
Recommendations and input of the chief information security officer are usually included within a
security program, but that would not be the primary benefit of implementing a security program as part of
a security governance framework.
justifications.D:
The impact of the implementation of a security program on the cost of IT security is uncertain. It may or
may not be reduced.

questions.question:
An employee who has access to highly confidential information resigned. Upon departure, which of the
following should be done FIRST?

options.A: Conduct an exit interview with the employee.
options.B: Ensure succession plans are in place.
options.C: Revoke the employee's access to all systems.
options.D: Review the employee's job history.

justifications.A:
It is important to have an exit interview with any employee; however, this is not the first step to take upon
the employee's departure to protect the confidentiality of information.
justifications.B:
Succession plans are important to prevent disruption of operations. This addresses availability and not
confidentiality of information.
justifications.C:
If an employee has dealt with highly classified information, the first step is to revoke their access
to all systems, to restrict access to the confidential information and thereby prevent exfiltration of
data.
justifications.D:
Reviewing the job history of an employee might be important to determine the functions the person
performed, but its effectiveness in terms of confidentiality of information may be limited.

questions.question:
An organization has outsourced its help desk activities. An information systems (IS) auditor's GREATEST
concern when reviewing the contract and associated service level agreement between the organization and
vendor should be the provisions for:

options.A: documentation of staff background checks.
options.B: independent audit reports or full audit access.
options.C: reporting the year-to-year incremental cost reductions.
options.D: reporting staff turnover, development or training.

justifications.A:
Although it is necessary to document the fact that background checks are performed, this is only one of
the provisions that should be in place for audits.
justifications.B:
When the functions of an IT department are outsourced, an information systems (IS) auditor
should ensure that a provision is made for independent audit reports that cover all essential areas,
or that the outsourcer has full audit access.
justifications.C:
Financial measures, such as year-to-year incremental cost reductions, are desirable to have in a service
level agreement (SLA); however, cost reductions are not as important as the availability of independent
audit reports or full audit access.
justifications.D:
An SLA might include human relationship measures, such as resource planning, staff turnover,
development or training, but this is not as important as the requirements for independent reports or
full audit access by the outsourcing organization.
158

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor identifies that reports on product profitability produced by an
organization's finance and marketing departments give different results. Further investigation reveals that
the product definition being used by the two departments is different. What should the IS auditor recommend?

options.A: User acceptance testing occurs for all reports before release into production.
options.B: Organizational data governance practices are put in place.
options.C: Standard software tools are used for report development.
options.D: Management signs off on requirements for new reports.

justifications.A:
User acceptance testing supports the process of ensuring that the system is production ready and satisfies
all documented requirements. Recommending that user acceptance testing occur for all reports before
release into production does not address the root cause of the problem described.
justifications.B:
Data governance directly addresses the problem. An organizationwide approach is needed to
achieve effective management of data assets and reporting standards. This includes enforcing
standard definitions of data elements, which is part of a data governance initiative.
justifications.C:
The use of standard software tools is one way of achieving uniformity across the different reports and
makes support of implemented reports easier. Therefore, recommending standard software tools be used
for report development does not address the root cause of the problem described.
justifications.D:
The sign-off by management indicates that they believe all requirements, functions and features have been
identified and documented. Recommending that management sign off on requirements for new reports
does not address the root cause of the problem described.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST supports the prioritization of new IT projects?

options.A: Internal control self-assessment (CSA)
options.B: Information systems (IS) audit
options.C: Investment portfolio analysis
options.D: Business risk assessment

justifications.A:
Internal control self-assessment (CSA) may highlight noncompliance with the current policy but may not
necessarily be the best source for driving the prioritization of IT projects.
justifications.B:
Like internal CSA, information systems (IS) audits are mostly a detective control and may provide only
part of the picture for the prioritization of IT projects.
justifications.C:
It is most desirable to conduct an investment portfolio analysis, which not only presents a clear
focus on investment strategy but also provides the rationale for terminating nonperforming IT
projects.
justifications.D:
Business risk analysis is part of the investment portfolio analysis but, by itself, is not the best method for
prioritizing new IT projects.
159

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST important information systems (IS) audit consideration when an
organization outsources a customer credit review system to a third-party service provider? The provider:

options.A: claims to meet or exceed industry security standards.
options.B: agrees to be subject to external security reviews.
options.C: has a good market reputation for service and experience.
options.D: complies with security policies of the organization.

justifications.A:
Compliance with security standards is important, but there is no way to verify or prove that is the case
without an independent review.
justifications.B:
An independent security review of an outsourcing vendor is critical because customer credit
information will be kept with the vendor
justifications.C:
Although long experience in business and a good reputation is an important factor in assessing service
quality, the business cannot outsource to a provider whose security control is weak.
justifications.D:
Compliance with organizational security policies is important, but there is no way to verify or prove that
that is the case without an independent review.

questions.question:
After the merger of two organizations, multiple self-developed legacy applications from both organizations
are to be replaced by a new common platform. Which of the following is the GREATEST risk?

options.A:
Project management and progress reporting are combined in a project management office that is driven by
external consultants.
options.B:
The replacement effort consists of several independent projects without integrating the resource allocation
in a portfolio management approach.
options.C:
The resources of each of the organizations are inefficiently allocated while they are being familiarized with
the other organization's legacy systems.
options.D: The new platform will force the business areas of both organizations to change their work processes, which

justifications.A:
In postmerger integration programs, it is common to form project management offices (often staffed with
external experts) to ensure standardized and comparable information levels in the planning and reporting
structures, and to centralize dependencies of project deliverables or resources.
justifications.B:
The efforts should be consolidated to ensure alignment with the overall strategy of the postmerger
organization. If resource allocation is not centralized, the separate projects are at risk of
overestimating the availability of key knowledge resources for the in-house-developed legacy
applications.
justifications.C:
The development of new integrated systems can require some knowledge of the legacy systems to gain an
understanding of each business process.
justifications.D:
In most cases, mergers result in application changes and, thus, in training needs as organizations and
processes change to leverage the intended synergy effects of the merger.
160 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question:
During an audit, an information systems (IS) auditor notices that the IT department of a medium-sized
organization has no separate risk management function, and the organization's operational risk documentation
only contains a few broadly described types of IT risk. What is the MOST appropriate recommendation in
this situation?

options.A:
Create an IT risk management department and establish an IT risk framework with the aid of external risk
management experts.
options.B:
Use common industry standard aids to divide the existing risk documentation into several individual types
of risk, which will be easier to handle.
options.C:
No recommendation is necessary because the current approach is appropriate for a medium-sized
organization.
options.D: Establish regular IT risk management meetings to identify and assess risk and create a mitigation plan as

justifications.A:
A medium-sized organization does not normally have a separate IT risk management department due
to limited resources. Moreover, the IT risk can usually be managed without the assistance of external
experts.
justifications.B:
Although common risk may be covered by industry standards, they cannot address the specific situation
of an organization. Individual types of risk will not be discovered without a detailed assessment from
within the organization. Splitting the one risk position into several is not sufficient to manage IT risk.
justifications.C:
The auditor should recommend a formal IT risk management effort because a few broadly described types
of IT risk contained in the operational risk documentation are insufficient. The failure to demonstrate
responsible IT risk management may be a liability for the organization.
justifications.D:
Establishing regular IT risk management meetings is the best way to identify and assess IT-related
risk in a medium-sized organization, to address responsibilities with the respective management
and to keep the risk register and mitigation plans up to date.

questions.question: Overall quantitative business risk for a particular threat can be expressed as:

options.A: a product of the likelihood and magnitude of the impact if a threat successfully exploits a vulnerability.
options.B: the magnitude of the impact if a threat source successfully exploits the vulnerability.
options.C: the likelihood of a given threat source exploiting a given vulnerability.
options.D: the collective judgment of the risk assessment team.

justifications.A:
Quantitative risk analysis methods use numeric values to describe the likelihood and impacts of
risk. Thus, the overall business risk can be expressed as the likelihood of the occurrence and
magnitude of the impact when a threat exploits a vulnerability and provides the best measure of the
risk to an asset.
justifications.B:
A threat source is the intent and method targeted at the intentional exploitation of a vulnerability or a
situation and method that may accidentally trigger a vulnerability. A threat is an event or situation that
has the potential for causing undesirable consequences or impact. The calculation of risk must consider
impact and likelihood of a threat (not a threat source) exploiting a vulnerability.
justifications.C:
The likelihood and impact of a threat (not a threat source) needs to be considered when determining
business risk, not just the likelihood.
justifications.D:
The collective judgment of the risk assessment team is a part of qualitative risk assessment but must be
combined with calculations of the impact on the business to determine overall risk.
161
